PARA.TAB: For the sake of those opposite who seem to be so confused about this and about the scope of the work of the Inter-State Commission, let me make absolutely clear what the work of the Inter-State Commission encompassed. Its work encompassed all road users from the family car through to road trains, as can be seen, for example, in the table on page 171 of its March 1990 report, which I table. It can be seen from that table that its work encompassed the whole area of road vehicles. It goes from cars and station wagons up to articulated trucks of seven axles or more. So it is clear that the work of the Inter-State Commission encompassed all road users, from the family car to road trains.

The Commission produced estimates of the levy that would be required on both diesel fuel and petrol to recover the purely distance element in road use charges. The details of the charges are contained in a table on page 181 of the Commission's report that I have tabled. From that table it is quite clear that it was applied to all classes of vehicles.

Following the July 1991 Special Premiers Conference, we announced agreement on the establishment of the National Road Transport Commission and we asked that it determine charges for heavy vehicles by March 1992, with a view to having the new system for heavy vehicles in place by 1 January 1993.

Under the principle of revenue neutrality governing the Premiers Conference processes, the pure distance element in the road user charge collected as a levy on diesel is to replace a component of the present diesel excise, so there will be no consequent change in the price of diesel fuel. In other words, there will be no add-on; it will be a replacement of a component of excise.

For lighter vehicles the issues are more complex and the revenues much larger, as can be seen from that table. It was judged desirable that work on these issues continue, as it sensibly should have done, in the context of the work on Federal-State financial relations. TALK.START.PARA: —The aim of the JET program—jobs, education and training—as its advertising slogan suggests is to enable sole parents to go back to work without neglecting their most important job, that is, looking after their children. It is based on a fundamental principle that all Australians should be able to care for their children, but that nobody should be excluded from the work force if that person is able and willing to participate. The jobs, education and training program is a voluntary program. The mother has a choice, often a difficult choice, but nevertheless she has a choice. Often the mother will find it almost impossible to work because of recurring illnesses with children, because the children are not doing well at school or because of a range of other factors. So the Government provides a safety net of the sole parent pension. The contrast of the policies announced by the Opposition last week are indeed very stark. It would deny sole parents the opportunity to care for their children. In its Fightback! document it proposed to increase the dependent spouse rebate for families with children up to age 25 years so that the wives of all those on incomes of up to $75,000 have the choice—
—What is wrong with that?

—There is nothing wrong with that. The honourable member asks, `What is wrong with that?'. There would be an opportunity provided by way of the dependent spouse rebate for families with children, up to the age of 25 years I remind the honourable member for Bennelong, so that wives of all those on an income of up to $75,000 have the choice of how to care for their children. But in the same statement sole parent families with children who have reached the age of 12 years are told to choose the tax payer, effectively, ahead of children. They are told, `Go and get full time work regardless of your children's needs'. That is in fact the instruction that is included within the so called Fightback! document. We have a justification from the Leader of the Opposition in the Sunday Age where he says, `In many two parent families both parents work while their children are still at school. In line with these developments it is no longer fair for sole parents to continue to receive the sole parent pension once their youngest child turns 12'. Or as Senator Richard Alston said to Ramona Koval, `My children are not psychologically scarred and my wife works from 9 to 5'. So we have the situation where the Opposition has put forward a proposal to the Australian people that says that the circumstances of a sole parent, someone responsible for bringing up children alone and someone who has children at that stage when they move into the early stages of adolescents and the early stage of puberty, essentially at a point which is critical in the life of a child, someone who has the responsibility alone to care for that child without any support and who takes the responsibility within the family for the child—I think the Leader of the Opposition would understand what the situation is—

—by leave—Today I am announcing major changes to the organisational form and management arrangements of the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service. The changes follow an intensive process of review initiated by me last December and reflect the broad thrust of proposals contained in submissions from industry and unions; from independent consultants Ernst and Young; and from the Quarantine and Inspection Policy Council.

PARA.TAB: The significance of the changes to Australia's trading interests should not be underestimated. Food inspection and certification—covering animal, plant and human health—provides the basis for continued entry to overseas markets. Quarantine protects producers and consumers, and our environment, from exotic pests and diseases. It also helps in meeting overseas requirements for our products to be free of pests and diseases.

Australia is a leading world producer of food. Not only do we provide about 95 per cent of our local needs, but also we are the world's second largest exporter of meat, the fourth largest of wheat and a major international source of dairy produce, grains and a range of other food exports. Food exports and related produce generated over $9.5 billion in export income in 1990-91. It is in this context that AQIS has a vital role to play in safeguarding Australia's trading interests and protecting Australian industries and consumers.

Control or exclusion of animal and plant diseases, and pests which are endemic in other countries, contribute to the well-being of Australians and give our producers a competitive advantage in markets overseas. The growing concern about food safety worldwide underlines the importance of maintaining firm control over chemical residues and other contaminants in foodstuffs.

Quarantine policies and operations keep out exotic pests and diseases which could damage or destroy agricultural industries or fisheries. It similarly helps to protect the natural environment. Inspection of export foodstuffs, plants and animals to meet the requirements of other countries is a prerequisite for trade. Inspection of food for domestic consumption, whether produced in Australia or imported, protects Australian consumers.

AQIS has an annual budget in 1991-92 of $179m, including $41m to fund quarantine and inspection operations performed on behalf of the Commonwealth by State and Territory government agencies. There are approximately 2,400 direct employees, and the equivalent of 700 quarantine and inspection staff employed by the States.

The costs of providing quarantine and inspection services are recovered from users wherever appropriate. The introduction of full cost recovery from January 1991 has greatly intensified scrutiny of AQIS's efficiency by those who pay its bills. The amount subject to cost recovery this financial year is $147m. AQIS's activities must be conducted as efficiently as possible and with a strong focus on its clients' circumstances and needs.

AQIS is now five years old. It has achieved the objectives set out in its first strategic plan five years ago. Its quarantine risk assessment procedures are amongst the most progressive in the world. A single quarantine service integrating animal, plant and general quarantine functions has been implemented. Many quarantine procedures have been streamlined and the establishment of private quarantine stations has been facilitated. On the inspection side, the recommendations of the 1982 royal commission have largely been implemented and the reputation of the Meat Inspection Service has been re-established.

Following modifications to inspection standards and procedures and the progressive introduction of new approaches based on quality assurance systems, the number of AQIS inspection staff has declined from about 2,250 to below 1,650—even though throughput is higher. AQIS's prompt and professional response to the residue crisis which threatened Australia's meat export trade to the USA in 1987, and in other similar situations before and since, has maintained access for our products in overseas markets. An inspection scheme for imported foods has been established and there are many other achievements which could also be mentioned.

The challenges AQIS faces now are different but no less demanding. New threats must be evaluated rapidly and appropriate action taken. The stakes are very high: a single lapse in quarantine effectiveness which permitted entry of foot and mouth disease in cattle or Newcastle disease in poultry could decimate Australian industry and cause losses running to billions of dollars.

At the same time, however, quarantine decisions must not unduly impede trade nor impose excessive restrictions on the importation of new genetic material needed by Australian primary producers. Furthermore, AQIS must maintain the confidence of Australians that its risk management decisions are well considered and based on sound science.

Australia's favourable pest and disease status compared with that of many other countries and the high quality of our primary produce give us a marketing advantage overseas which can be nullified by arbitrary and unjustified quarantine restrictions or food standards applied by authorities in importing countries. If the GATT Uruguay Round is successful in restricting the use of conventional measures to protect domestic agriculture such as markets access restrictions, protectionist-inclined countries may try to erect alternative barriers in the form of quarantine controls or food standards.

AQIS must use bilateral and multilateral forums to spotlight and oppose any trade barriers disguised as sanitary or phytosanitary measures. The excessive inspection requirements imposed on our meat exports by the USA and the EC will be a major focus of attention for AQIS.

The cost of quarantine and inspection services is significant in total, even if it is not a substantial component in the cost structure of user industries. AQIS cannot merely limit the rate of increase of costs; it must continue to actively pursue real cost reductions by all possible means.

In this regard, AQIS is very much part of the Government's agenda for micro-economic reform. Regulation must be the minimum necessary to meet the circumstances and industry must be encouraged to assume a greater degree of responsibility. Charging policies must encourage efficient use of public sector resources. With that background in mind, let me now turn to future arrangements.

Over the next five years AQIS will maintain its fine record in protecting human, animal and plant health in Australia and ensuring access for Australian products overseas through its quarantine and inspection functions. But it will become significantly smaller in terms of its staff numbers and in terms of its total cost to users—without compromising effectiveness or integrity.

The substitution of traditional AQIS product inspection by industry quality assurance schemes audited by AQIS will accelerate, with the benefit of the additional development support committed by the Government in the 1990-91 Budget. Operations staff will be more highly trained and will possess a wider range of skills.

Scientific competence will be built up. Cost effectiveness will be enhanced by structural change, regulatory reform and investment in human and technical resources. Communication with client groups will be strengthened through formal structures and issue-related strategies.

AQIS will maintain its leadership role in international multilateral activities and strongly pursue bilateral agreements advantageous to Australian trading interests. The Service will adopt a quality management approach to all its activities. The strategies which will turn this vision into reality will build upon the major reforms already under way. To quote the independent management consultants, Ernst and Young:

AQIS is, by its own initiative, a highly reformist organisation. Over the last several years AQIS has been undergoing a process of major change directed towards reducing the cost and improving the quality of inspection services. . . There is a clear vision on the part of top management within AQIS for a more efficient, effective and responsive quarantine and inspection service based on Quality Assurance principles with industry taking greater responsibility for providing traditional inspection tasks.

The centrepiece of AQIS's strategies for the next five years is the continued transition from traditional inspection approaches, serving both quarantine and food standard objectives, to the widespread adoption of quality assurance approaches.

Under quality assurance, responsibility for ensuring that a product meets quality requirements rests in the first instance with the producer, who must design, implement and maintain systems for this purpose and demonstrate competency in their use. Quality assurance systems are built into the production process, reducing reliance on end product inspection.

It must be emphasised that the quality assurance approach in no way involves any abrogation of AQIS's ultimate responsibility to ensure that statutory or other requirements are met. There will be no reduction in the quality or reliability of Australian products as a consequence of switching to quality assurance systems as the best means of achieving regulatory objectives. In particular, AQIS will ensure that quality assurance options are underpinned by firm and effective sanctions policies.

AQIS has already managed the introduction of quality assurance approaches for fish inspection, dairy exports, export cold stores and, in a specialised form, certain activities in export abattoirs. As a consequence, industry has been relieved of the need to pay for a significant number of inspectors. Changes now approved for domestic meat inspection practices represent a major extension. Indeed, the quality assurance approach to be developed and trialled for use on slaughter floors in domestic abattoirs is probably the most advanced in the world.

While AQIS is managing the introduction of quality assurance options in food and quarantine control in an evolutionary way, the consequences for industry may be revolutionary. AQIS's approach is a catalyst for a major change in culture and methods in industry.

To take one example, meat processing is one of Australia's larger and most competitive manufacturing industries. Its production methodology and employment practices, however, are traditional and it has a surplus of production capacity in old, outdated abattoirs spread across Australia. Commitment to quality is often poor.

It is extremely difficult for AQIS to provide inspection services efficiently to this industry on an on-demand basis. Introduction of a quality assurance based approach shifts responsibility to industry in the first instance to address the difficulties of achieving appropriate standards in this operating environment.

The second broad strategy for AQIS is to reinforce its scientific competency. Since the Government adopted the recommendations of the Lindsay Committee on quarantine policy, AQIS has been developing a formal quarantine risk assessment procedure. Assessed risk has always been the basis of AQIS's decisions about particular quarantine issues such as the conditions, if any, under which importation of commodities from overseas can be allowed.

However, the increasing requirement to be able to fully justify quarantine restrictions to domestic constituencies and international trading partners requires formal risk assessment based on sound science. In this regard AQIS is served by the Bureau of Rural Resources and by its own existing scientific staff in the provision of scientific analysis, and it will enhance its capabilities in this area. Similar considerations apply to food science and technology in AQIS.

International developments underline the crucial importance of scientific excellence for AQIS's activities. There is now a strong probability that, as part of an agreed outcome in the Uruguay Round, the GATT contracting parties will conclude an agreement to prevent the misuse of food standards and quarantine control as unjustified technical barriers to trade.

Under that agreement on so-called sanitary and phytosanitary measures, countries which are not following international standards when setting food standards or quarantine restrictions may be challenged to justify their approach. The justification must show that national requirements are based on sound science, risk assessment and consistency in risk management. AQIS may be called upon to provide such an explanation. Therefore it must ensure that the sanitary and phytosanitary measures which it applies have a competent scientific basis.

It is also important that a new GATT agreement on sanitary and phytosanitary measures can be the means by which Australia can exert leverage to improve our access to markets overseas, provided we have superior technical and scientific argument in support of our case.

A major theme among strategies for the future is the need for AQIS to adopt a more business-like approach. The report from Ernst and Young put its main emphasis on this point. AQIS will be more business-like in future, and not only because it must now cover its `commercial costs'.

`Business-like' means cost-consciousness; it means efficient resource use; it means market and customer orientation; it means a commitment to serving the interests of its stakeholders; and it means being competitive and entrepreneurial.

I shall be communicating with the State and Territory Ministers responsible for the agencies which deliver quarantine services in the field to discuss the adoption of a more business-like approach in their activities also. Considering Australia's need for sustained improvement in our export performance, the Government believes that AQlS's more business-like approach must be focused primarily in that direction.

There is a widespread perception that AQIS's operations unduly inhibit the export potential of Australia's food and livestock industries, whereas controls over competing imported foodstuffs are more relaxed. Similar concerns have been expressed in relation to quarantine controls. These perceptions, which are incorrect, probably derive largely from AQIS's role in ensuring that the requirements of other countries which are importing Australian produce are met.

In general, AQIS intervenes in the export process to ensure that Australian products are of a standard such that they will be permitted to enter foreign markets. In addition, there is an overriding international obligation to ensure that food exported from Australia is fit for human consumption and that animals and plants which are exported are healthy. In pursuing these goals, AQIS will carry out its functions in a manner which aids export activities to the maximum extent.

AQIS will develop and implement an export facilitation program, a particular feature of which will be the better utilisation of AQIS's considerable professional knowledge in the spheres of food and livestock trade. AQIS already provides detailed advice on demand to intending exporters on conditions of entry applying to foodstuffs and livestock in overseas markets, and it circulates information to trade associations on prospective changes to entry conditions as they become known. It is likely that entry conditions will tend to become more restrictive and complex as consumer awareness of potential hazards associated with foodstuffs increases.

To improve access to advice on these matters, AQIS will now identify and train individual officers at regional locations and in AQIS's Canberra office as export facilitators accessible through a toll free telephone line. Callers will either receive an immediate response or be transferred to an officer who has special expertise in a particular area.

A second element of the program will be the preparation and dissemination of advisory notes on regulatory matters which frequently cause problems in export trading. The information program will be guided by a survey of exporters' needs in this area. AQIS will also develop its linkages with Austrade, the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade and the various statutory marketing authorities for agricultural commodities.
AQIS's professional and technical staff will be available, on a consultancy basis, to contribute to the development of export marketing plans in their specialist areas of expertise.
Further information on this and other elements of the program will be circulated in the near future.

To develop a more business-like approach to financial management within AQIS, the Government has decided that AQIS will operate under the financial discipline of a trust account into which cost recovery revenues will be paid and from which expenditures will be funded. The Government will still meet the cost of `government business' and quarantine surveillance by Budget appropriation. The non-user attributable components of AQIS costs will be reviewed in 1992.

The discipline of operating on a trust account basis requiring services to be self-funded will reinforce cost-consciousness in AQIS. For many who pay for AQIS's services, however, the central consideration in a more business-like approach is whether AQIS is offering its inspection and other services not only at least cost but also in the precise form which best suits the purchaser. Abattoir operators, for example, expect inspection services to be provided wherever and whenever they want them, and some at least do not expect to be charged for on-costs such as superannuation or for administrative overheads.

The Government's view is that the full costs of providing services must be met by users. The meat processing industry must meet the costs which AQIS incurs because of the geographic dispersion of the industry, seasonal fluctuations in activity, inefficiencies caused by abattoir design, and so on. It is not reasonable to make taxpayers bear the burden.

Part of a more business-like approach is accountability to `customers' and stake-holders. As from this year, AQIS will prepare and publish an annual report, additional to the coverage of the service in the annual report of the Department of Primary Industries and Energy. AQIS's five-year strategic corporate plan will be published shortly for the information of all interested parties.

It is also timely to revamp the Quarantine and Inspection Policy Council which has served as the peak advisory body to the responsible Minister for the past four years. A new body, the Quarantine and Inspection Advisory Council, will be responsible for advising me on AQIS's broad strategies, the direction and priority of programs and services, resource issues, technical developments, and economic and industry considerations. Unlike the QIPC, the new Council's membership will be selected on the basis of specific expertise rather than, as was the case in the past, to represent particular client groups. It will be expected to consult widely, including with industry, and it will be kept fully informed of AQIS's relations with client groups.

One of the first tasks of the new Council will be to review established consultative arrangements between AQIS and interested parties and suggest any appropriate improvements. In particular, the Council will be asked to consider Ernst and Young's proposal that two new industry consultative councils be established.

I take this opportunity to thank the Chairman of the QIPC, Mr Bill Meynink, CBE, and the members of the Council for their valuable service to the Government and the nation in the interests of quarantine control and food inspection.

To implement the strategies I have described, a number of important administrative changes will be made to AQIS. The most significant will be the creation of a new position of business manager responsible for human resources, financial services and information technology. The business manager will also have responsibility for the oversight of commercial consultancy developments. One major focus for the business manager will be industrial relations.

The changes in prospect for AQIS are of fundamental concern to its staff. Over the past five years AQIS has managed the introduction of major change with minimal industrial disruption by emphasising planning, consultation and communication, together with a program of investment in human resources to fit AQIS's capabilities to the needs of the 1990s and beyond. One major element in AQIS's training effort is the development of purpose built tertiary level courses in food technology, which a significant number of AQIS inspection staff are successfully undertaking. These policies will continue. The process of introducing new methods and rationalising across all AQIS functions will accelerate and so will the reduction in staff numbers.

As a result of the changes I am announcing today, I expect that the inspection work force will decline by about 25 per cent over the next two to three years. It is difficult to be more precise because the demand for inspection by AQIS depends on the rate at which industry takes up quality assurance options. The Government has provided in the order of $20m to fund a redundancy program over the period to 1993-94. The Government is shouldering this burden of adjustment as part of its desire to foster greater efficiency and competitiveness in Australia's food and livestock exporting industries.

AQIS has recently completed an award restructuring agreement with inspection staff which provides for a number of significant changes. A new unified structure will provide the framework for employment of inspectors as food standards officers with the capacity through additional skill training to work across the range of commodities. The upgrading of skills has a particular focus on expertise in auditing, as the logical complement of AQIS's push to make quality assurance options available to industry as an alternative to intensive, on-line inspection procedures.

The award restructuring package also encourages a significant reduction in supervisory staff at meat processing establishments and increased flexibility in supply of AQIS services by means of provisions for seasonal and part time employment and for relocation of staff when, for example, establishments serviced by AQIS close down operations.

Executive management structure will also be revised. A corporate management group comprising the Executive Director and the heads of the quarantine, food inspection and business management groups will have responsibility for corporate decision-making. AQIS's regional directors, who have line responsibility for implementation of food inspection programs, will have a somewhat broader mandate in future and, in particular, will have a collegiate role in overall program delivery. Where AQIS has been the subject of debate in recent times, a central issue has been whether AQIS should be converted to a statutory authority .

Management consultants Ernst and Young concluded that no significant near term improvements in efficiency would flow from conversion to statutory authority status, and that such status would not be appropriate until the processes of change and improvement in the meat inspection industry are further advanced. The QIPC also concluded that AQIS should not be made a statutory authority at present, but should nonetheless actively pursue options for corporatisation or statutory form.

In my view, there would be significant costs in administrative effort and much industry opposition to an immediate shift to statutory authority status. This option may—I believe will—become more appropriate three to five years hence and, accordingly, will be the subject of further review by 1994.

As I mentioned earlier, the maintenance of Australia's reputation as a producer of clean, high quality food is critical to the continuing marketability of Australian produce and therefore to the health of our food production industries. AQIS's role on food safety is reflected not only in the conduct of its regulatory functions but also in promotion of quality assurance approaches, liaison with counterpart agencies overseas and other activities. Within the Department of Primary Industries and Energy, AQIS will have the coordinating role on food safety matters. AQIS will strongly develop its linkages with the new National Food Authority, which has responsibility for developing Australia's food standards.

I am aware that in its recent pronouncement on a goods and services tax the Opposition has had something to say about AQIS. There is a proposal also for a $19m saving through a cut in administrative costs and a $10m cut in the salaries bill for inspection.

It would not be appropriate for me to go into detail in this statement, but these suggestions are at best improbable. The suggested reduction in administrative costs could be achieved only if there was a significant decrease in the effectiveness of quarantine services provided by State and Territory governments. The risk of exposure to overseas pests and diseases would as a corollary increase. Large cuts in salary costs are achievable only by means of a large scale redundancy program and, as I pointed out earlier in this statement, involve even greater up-front expenditure by the Government on redundancy packages. I hope that the Opposition will, nonetheless, consider this statement thoughtfully, instead of subordinating its views on AQIS to its wider political agenda.

I conclude this statement by repeating that AQIS is already a competent organisation which has crucial roles to play in support of Australian primary industry, our national environment and the welfare of Australians. It is well advanced on a major program of change. The Government has decided that the change process should be broadened and accelerated in key areas.

The reforms I have announced today will ensure that AQIS enhances its already high international reputation for integrity and professional performance. Cost savings, greater efficiency in export performance, a more commercial operation, and a scientifically-based commitment to food safety and consumer concerns are part of AQlS's contribution to the `clever country'. I commend the reforms to the House. I present the following paper:

Neither of these organisations, nor for that matter the coalition parties in this Parliament, have any faith in the Government's handling of AQIS, or of the so-called independent report, which the Minister commissioned earlier this year. On today's Country Hour cattle councillor Ian Steele-Park said:

SPEECH.PARA: The inquiry that Mr Griffiths instituted only a few months ago was simply a `Claytons'. The terms of reference were designed by AQIS and the consultancy firm was chosen by AQIS, so to me that was a complete and utter farce.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was a snow job.

—It was. Mr Steele-Park went on to say that AQIS itself is becoming seriously embarrassed by the adverse publicity and the comments being made against it. When the Ernst and Young report was released in July, Mr Ed Wright, the Chairman of the Cattle Council and also the Chairman of the National Farmers Federation AQIS Task Force, was reported to have said:

SPEECH.PARA: "Ernst and Young have failed to `grasp the nettle' of sweeping reform for AQIS; something which NFF considers is desperately needed," said Mr Wright.
"The consultants argue that the creation of AQIS as a statutory authority `at this stage' was unnecessary to continue the drive for greater efficiency.
I am puzzled as to why the wishes of the majority of industry, and AQIS itself, have been ignored in their call for the corporatisation of the Service," said Mr Wright.
"Cynically, one could argue that Ernst and Young have been distracted by organisations or people who have a vested interest in the status quo.

They seem to have placed little credence in the fact that industry, not Government, is footing a bill of $450,000/day for what is perceived to be a grossly inefficient service relative to businesses within the private sector, corporatisation would inject a degree of much-needed commercial reality into the Service without jeopardising its integrity.

If the Minister maintains AQIS as a pure public service, as suggested, he would be ignoring the Government's much-flaunted drive for greater commercial reality within the public sector and ignoring industry's potential role in such a drive.
But the Minister does make one telling comment and acknowledges one of the real credibility problems facing AQIS today. In the Minister's speech he said:
The introduction of full cost recovery from January 1991 has greatly intensified scrutiny of AQIS's efficiency by those who pay its bills.
The Minister is certainly right about that, because the people who will pay the $147m for inspection charges know and are saying repeatedly and loudly that they are not getting value for money.

PARA.TAB: Meat inspectors receive a salary of about $32,000, but AQIS charges the abattoir $68,000 for each inspector to cover add-on costs such as regional offices and a head office and those on idle time. We have another industry—the waterfront—which operates a bit like that. This idle time creates real costs for all industries through the system, including the meat export industry. The Minister, in answer to questions, has admitted that there are 63 meat inspectors who are stationed in places where abattoirs have closed. Some have been closed for five years.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are still there?

—Yes. In answer to a question asked in a Senate Estimates committee it was admitted that 45 of these inspectors had refused transfers, but the Department claims that most of them are used as relief staff or in nearby abattoirs. However, this is contradicted by information obtained from the Department that shows that they are only half utilised and had been sent all over Australia. That is one simple example of where, if people refuse to move to where the work is, they should no longer be employed when there are so many people surplus to the needs.

PARA.TAB: In May this year there were 1,654 meat inspectors; 1,249 of those were directly employed in inspection at any one time. This means that there are always 405 inspectors, or 25 per cent, not engaged in inspection.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is unbelievable.

—Nevertheless, it is true. Of these, 87 inspectors were deemed to be surplus to requirements and a further 155 are estimated to become surplus within the next two years. On top of that, there are 162 inspectors who provide relief for those on holidays, sick leave, et cetera. So much for the 45 who were supposed to be doing that. To cover the cost of these inspectors who do not earn a direct recovery from the industry, a figure of $14,200 is loaded on every working inspector. Despite the number of surplus inspectors and those refusing transfers, AQIS employed another 14 inspectors during the last 12 months.

PARA.TAB: The problems are not only in the meat industry. I constantly receive complaints from people exporting other products which must be inspected. I am getting quite a number of complaints—and my colleague the shadow Minister for aviation, the honourable member for Fadden (Mr Jull), gets these also—about the charge for weekend air exports and air freight services which are used to maintain fresh contracts, and also to develop export markets with small orders. To be fair, that is not a criticism of the inspectors; it should be a criticism of the Government for arranging that type of uncompetitive inspection cost.

In addition, the documentation system for exports required by DPIE is, to quote one of the kinder comments I have heard, antiquated. The Department is supposedly developing a better system, but it is still between 18 months and two years away. Customs has a system in place now which could easily be extended to include these exports. This system was actually offered to DPIE but it was not accepted. So much for this drive to be more businesslike.

The Minister has spoken about improvements in efficiency through the implementation of the quality assurance program; that is, putting emphasis back on the abattoir itself. He makes the valid point that the abattoir owners, the meat processors themselves, also have to take responsibility for ensuring the rapid implementation of this scheme. The Minister says that the number of inspectors has declined from 2,250 to fewer than 1,650 and there is a higher throughput. How does that relate to the fact that there are 2,400 people employed by AQIS, and 700 quarantine and inspection staff employed by the States? Does that mean that out of a total of 3,100 people only 1,650 are inspectors, and that for every person in the field there is another sitting in an office being paid by clients? I accept the point about the other roles of AQIS, but I do believe we need a better answer than the one we have had so far on how effectively that staff is being employed.

The Minister talked about quality assurance and the implementation of this service. This has been introduced first of all for fish and dairy exports, where inspectors are being removed from the line, and now it is being extended to domestic meat inspection. But there is another problem that is obvious from all these overhead costs that are still there. People involved in those industries say that they are not benefiting from any reduction in costs. Once again, one can look at a comparison with the waterfront, where there may be an improvement in the movement of containers per hour, but it will be from three to five years before there is any reduction in costs to the users because of all the deals and expensive arrangements that have been put in place as part of that process.

The Minister in his statement was critical of the coalition for indicating in its Fightback program that there will be net savings of $14m in the meat inspection service. This figure was tested with people in the industry. We were told universally that that sort of figure should be achievable quite easily because of what is known of those inefficiencies. The Minister, in providing his plan for the future and detailing a more businesslike culture for AQIS, referred to an export facilitation program, the establishment of a trust account, the publication of an annual report, a new Quarantine and Inspection Policy Council, and corporatisation that was considered but rejected and will be considered again in 1994. He added to what is already the feeling in industry that nothing really is being achieved by this Government.

What about the coalition policy; what about the coalition position? We have a commitment to create or require a completely commercial Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service for inspection purposes. The National Farmers Federation and the Cattle Council of Australia, as I have indicated earlier, have the view that at this time—I emphasise, at this time—with this Government, the best way to achieve a more commercial system is to corporatise that part of AQIS and to provide contractual arrangements.

The coalition is maintaining consultation with the industry.I am referring now to the time frame of a coalition government, which of course will commence after the next election. We have a commitment, and it is our policy, to remove all possible meat inspectors from on-line inspection—not just meat inspectors, but inspectors of food products—and also from the employment of AQIS, and to reduce the overhead management in a like form. It is our policy that the inspectors should be employed by the processing company, which will be responsible for its own quality and suffer the consequences if it is found wanting, and that a core of vets and inspectors be retained by AQIS for check testing.

This is not just a fanciful belief on the part of the coalition. Mr Dick Austin, Chairman of the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation, has spoken on the need for this to be achieved and the ability to achieve it. I also want to quote from Dr Paul Hopwood, Professor of Veterinary Science at the University of Sydney, who said very recently that:

SPEECH.PARA: Government inspectors are not cost effective because:-
. they need to be supervised by an expensive bureaucracy,
. they work under a public service award,
. they may not be responsive to the needs of industry or to the needs of individual works,
. they are industrially militant, and
. they have a high level of job security which is unrelated to work performance.
Dr Hopwood also said:
If AQIS has to decide between protecting its bureaucracy or providing cheaper meat inspection it will decide in its own favour every time.
He also suggests that meatworks need to undertake their total quality management as the only way to reduce costs.

PARA.TAB: Obviously, the second part of coalition policy is for AQIS to maintain the disease-free status of Australia. That is just not a role for that organisation; I refer to the positive work that can be done by ACIAR in research projects and joint ventures in countries near Australia, for example, to prevent Newcastle disease, foot and mouth disease or whatever from coming to this country.

The next point is that AQIS needs to be utilised to overcome non-tariff-barrier, quarantine-type access problems that keep our products out of markets, particularly in the Asia-Pacific Rim countries, where there is tremendous potential for trade. I will follow with interest one of the more positive points in the Minister's statement on the export facilitation program. I certainly acknowledge the slow but at last reasonable progress that is being made with the National Food Authority, and in that regard I would be more critical of State governments than the Federal Government.

The next part of our policy would be to require AQIS to obtain more equitable access to other countries in return for access to Australia for products from those countries where, for example, there was a similar disease—and one thinks here of the United States and citrus—or where similar area freedom protocols are being established. The next point would be that if AQIS wants to be treated as a professional organisation, then all of its members will be required to act professionally to provide its service irrespective of industrial action being taken outside abattoirs, as occurred recently, for example, with picket line incidents.

Equally businesslike changes to abattoir employment practices will be required under the next government, a coalition government. We have to reduce the terrible difference between the cost of killing and processing a cow in Australia and the cost in the United States. The cost of putting a cow or a steer through a Australian abattoir is 2 1/2 times the cost in the United States. That is a terrible indictment on work practices in this country. We are not talking about Third World countries or cheap labour; we are talking about work practices and productivity. We have to reduce costs right through the cattle industry and, for that matter, all industry in Australia to remain competitive, to create much needed regional employment, and to give the hard pressed cattle producer a little bit of profit for a change.

With the announcement of our Fightback package, with the goods and services tax in the place of all of those input costs, input taxes—fuel excise, wholesale sales tax, et cetera—we are making a big start, and we are determined to see that this happens in government—

TALK.START.PARA: —To give people a fair go.

—To give people in this country a fair go, to survive, to be profitable, to compete, and to be able to employ people. This is needed as much in our export food industries as it is anywhere else. AQIS and the inspection service generally will be required by a coalition government to make an equal contribution to that more efficient and competitive Australia.

Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Hollis)—Mr Speaker has received a letter from the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Reith) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:
The urgent necessity for the Government to embrace the sweeping reforms released last week in the coalition's Fightback program.

PROCTEXT.PARA: I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

TAB.EMPHASIS: More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places—

TALK.START.PARA: —In the Parliament today we saw the baton of government pass from a tired, discredited government to a new coalition charged with dynamism and enthusiasm to run this country better than it has been run for a very long time. The release last week of the coalition's Fightback package was truly a turning point in Australia's political history. It really was a watershed in the affairs of our nation.

PARA.TAB: When the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) got to his feet today in Question Time, after hundreds of hours of effort by all these Treasury boffins and their super models and their little models and their big models, he had absolutely no reply. He had no opinion of his own. All he could do was just parrot some old, tired left wing views that he had picked out of the papers this morning—the same old left wing views and the same sort of socialist ideology that have held this country back for 20 years, robbed people of the incentive to work, robbed people of the incentive to save and seen the worst recession in 60 years, a recession deliberately engineered by this Government.

At no stage in the first quarter of an hour that the Prime Minister was on his feet did he do anything but talk rhetoric. He loaded us up with rhetoric. He provided absolutely no alternative whatsoever. As for the Treasurer (Mr Kerin), he is just a broken, pathetic figure who has lost all self-confidence. All he could do was read from a written text prepared for him by the Treasury boffins.

The Minister for Resources (Mr Griffiths), in a disgraceful display, simply tried to mislead people in the most dishonest presentation that I have seen in Question Time for a very long time. He simply quoted press releases that were months old and that everybody knows were not true. Lastly, of course, we had the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Howe), who ended up in a shameful display of gutter politics from which he ultimately only reluctantly withdrew. I say to the Deputy Prime Minister that if he has a scintilla of decency left in him, he should come into the Parliament this afternoon and apologise for his disgraceful behaviour.

This all adds up to a government which is really in total disarray, a government which is on its last legs, a government that has run out of ideas and a government that is racked by internal faction fighting. If one looked at the faces on the Government backbenchers, one would have seen that they were glum. Their faces—with the exception of the smiling face of the honourable member for Blaxland (Mr Keating), who waits day by day with his knife sharpened—told a story of a government that really has run its course.

The Prime Minister and the Treasurer, who has just walked into the chamber, ought to have seen to their responsibilities and come into the Parliament prepared to debate the future of this country. It was revealing, was it not, that at the time when Question Time was to start, we moved a motion to provide the Treasurer, the person charged principally with the day to day economic management of this country, with an opportunity to stand and debate the issues in a sensible and considered way. But no, he ran a mile. He would not have a bar of sensible, constructive debate.

For months and months the Government has been calling for the release of our policy and calling for us to debate the details of our policy. Yet now that we have released it and given the Government an opportunity to do just that, it applies the gag. So the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) was justified today in moving a censure motion against the Prime Minister, and again it was no surprise that the Government backed off from the opportunity to debate the great issues raised last week by the coalition in its alternative Fightback program.

Let me make three preliminary points to the Treasurer. Firstly, he ought to account to the people of Australia for the massive waste of taxpayers' funds in the propaganda exercise that he is running in the Federal bureaucracy to attack the one good idea put up in recent years to advance Australia out of the economic problems caused by this Government. On Friday night at taxpayers' expense the Treasury was lit up like a Christmas tree while it was working on the coalition's package. That is not the function of the Treasury; its function is to look to the interests of the people of Australia and to prepare constructive solutions and propositions for the better management of this country. Its job is not to use taxpayers' funds to tear down coalition policies. It is a disgrace that in the worst recession for 60 years so many resources are being used within Treasury and the Department of Finance.

We have now found out that there are hordes of people working on this package in the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services, in the Department of Social Security and in the Department of Employment, Education and Training. And in what other departments? The Treasurer should answer this. Today he failed to answer the question as to how many people have been diverted to this political propaganda task. How many other people has he put into working on the attack by the Labor Party on the Opposition's policies?

Yesterday the Treasurer claimed that nobody was being paid overtime to do that work. That is patently wrong, and the Treasurer should admit it. He has had half an hour since Question Time to find out that this is the case. If we do not get straight answers from the Treasurer, he will get an FOI as quickly as I can say `Jack Robinson'.

Secondly, let me give the Treasurer some advice, as I think he has a few problems in his own backyard. He has Tony Cole, Greg Smith, Furnell and Ken Henry all working away to prepare the attack on the Opposition policy; but of course they all used to work for the honourable member for Blaxland. Beware of Greeks bearing gifts!

The second thing I say to the Treasurer is that he should not be too cocky. One member of his scare campaign team, one of the technicians, actually rang one of our economic consultants to find out how to do what we have been doing in the last few months, and that was so that the Treasurer could attack it. This is incredible. We have these huge taxpayers' resources put into this exercise, yet the Treasurer's staff are ringing the coalition's advisers to find out how to do it. I say to the Treasurer that he should not have too much confidence in the advice he will be getting from some of his boffins down there in Treasury.

Thirdly, I would say to the Treasurer that for months now Government members have had the idea that somehow our package would be a repeat of 1985. All the Government's rhetoric and all its silly arguments have been locked back into a time freeze of 1985, which just shows how far behind and off the pace the Government is. A lot has happened since 1985. The Government's proposition back in 1985, when the Labor Party itself wanted a consumption tax as part of tax reform, was but a minnow compared with what we released last week. For example, we have introduced a new tax credit system to look after the 800,000 people who in 1985 the Government was just going to throw onto the scrap heap.

We have introduced wealth compensation—the first time that has ever been proposed in the introduction of a value added tax system. We are simply miles ahead of the Government on that point. In 1985 the Government had no anti-inflation strategy. We placed the GST introduction within the context of an anti-inflation strategy built on sound money—something which is light years from where the Government was in 1985.

Whilst the Government's rhetoric has changed on wages policy, the fact is that back in 1985 the Government believed—and still does—in a centralised system. Yet much has changed in the Australian economy since then, in spite of the Government rather than because of it. And on one of the structural reform issues—privatisation—in 1985 the Government was running scare campaigns against it. How the world has changed! In the Treasurer's assessment of our package he ought to take that into account.

In the Fightback program we have presented a new approach for this country, a vision of our country in the year 2000. What a great moment it was today when the Leader of the Opposition tabled, by leave, the Fightback program in the Federal Parliament. I must say it was a great honour to be associated with the Fightback program and with the team that the leader of the coalition has gathered around him to bring this great undertaking to reality.

If I might look across to the Senate and just name a few senators—and it is always difficult to name names—I think Senator Short will be a great finance Minister for this country, Senator Alston will be great in social security and Senator John Watson is a great expert on tax matters.

In this House, for example, I think the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton) has a tremendous grasp of policy issues. The honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) has been in the vanguard of industrial relations reform for many years, and it is a great thing to see such reform as part of the centrepiece of the program released last week. What a tremendous job the Leader of the National Party, the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer), has done in his contribution towards Fightback. The honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock) was one of Australia's great foreign Ministers and is one of the great strengths in support of the Leader of the Opposition.

The honourable member for Pearce (Mr Chaney) has done a great job in the environment portfolio. The honourable member for Goldstein (Dr Kemp) has made a tremendous contribution and has brought political expertise to the Federal coalition. The honourable member for Lowe (Dr Bob Woods) has put up a great health policy for the coalition. What a great thing it is for the coalition to be able to put that together as part of an integrated package. The honourable member for Fadden (Mr Jull) sits there as an acknowledged expert, even by Government members, in the aviation and tourist industry. The honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer) has done a tremendous job in telling the Australian people about the huge raft of hidden consumption taxes they pay every day.

What a joke it is for the Labor Party to say that it is opposed to consumption taxes when it has put up consumption taxes every year it has been in office. The average Australian family pays between $45 and $50 a week in Labor's hidden consumption taxes, and that is a message we intend to continue to spread around the Australian community. What a great addition the honourable member for Barker (Mr McLachlan) has been to the Opposition's team. He gives us strength and depth. We have the honourable member for—

TALK.START.PARA: —O'Connor.

—I am happy to mention the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey). He came on board and it just shows that the coalition has a group of people prepared to work as a team. That is very important because ultimately we need a team of people which is prepared to work together in this country's long term best interests. Lastly, let me briefly turn to our leader, whose contribution to public debate in this country has reached a new standard in Australian politics. He has great intellectual force and capacity, but he also has a sense of humour and the ability to bring people together into a team and to share the understanding that, together, these great tasks can be faced and carried out.

PARA.TAB: That has made a great difference to our side of politics. The Leader of the Opposition has the capacity to bring the team together. He has a sense of what is right and what is wrong, and a political shrewdness and understanding of the Australian people that have allowed him to reach an important milestone in the political history of this country—his release last week of the Fightback program, a vision for the future of this country; something that the Australian people have yearned for for years.

There is, as the terms of the matter of public importance say, an urgent necessity for governments to embrace the broad and sweeping reforms which the coalition announced through the Leader of the Opposition last week. We have big problems in Australia. We cannot push them to one side, as the Government does, and say to people, `Look, things are going to be better'. The truth is that for nearly 20 years we have had some fundamental flaws in the Australian economy. Now we have one in three young people unemployed. Our country is literally addicted to debt—$130 billion and still climbing.

The great thing about Fightback is that it says to the Australian people, `We can fix our problems. If we are prepared to work together and take the tough decisions, this country can realise its great potential and be great again'. We come into the Parliament today with the Fightback program under our arm, proud to be members of the coalition and determined to see the implementation of a great program of reform that will push this country to the year 2000 with greater confidence and higher living standards. As we reach the year 2000 we will see once again Australia reaching its full potential. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I was going to take this matter of public importance seriously, but what we heard from the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith) was at the level of a chapter of the Toorak branch of the Liberal Party, so I do not think there is much sense in trying to address the sort of nonsensical garbage he went on with. Apparently the Opposition wants somehow to transform the Parliament into a debating forum about the Opposition's election manifesto. I am afraid that the Government is going to get on with the business of governing. It is not going to transform this House into a place where the views of the members of the Parliament are ignored.

PARA.TAB: The problem the Opposition faces is that this so-called matter of public importance has no substance. Its package ran out of petrol after about four days; there is simply no content in it. The most powerful thing said by the honourable member for Flinders was on the question of people in the Public Service working on the Opposition's package. This is a side issue and he used absolutely nonsensical arguments. He threatens this one and that one. Every time anyone criticises anything that is in the public marketplace of ideas—Professor Head, the Governor of the Reserve Bank, and Ross Gittins—they are immediately attacked.

I say to the honourable member for Flinders that I am not going to jump to his tune. He simply does not understand—or pretends he does not understand—what a public servant does. When I was a public servant I was quite happy to do work for a National Party Minister. The Opposition ought to understand that a politicised Public Service is one that will work for only one party. The closest thing we have had to a politicised public service in this country was in Queensland under the National Party. A non-politicised Public Service is one that will work for the government of the day in the public interest, aware of the ebb and flow of political issues, public debate, and the policy positions of the major political parties. We do not want public servants who are eunuchs. We are analysing the package in the interests of the public. This is quite standard practice. I well remember that during the 1980 election and the 1977 election exactly the same thing was done with our election platforms. It is part of the way that the Public Service operates, quite professionally.

As I said, there was not much content in the honourable gentleman's speech, and there is not much sense in dignifying it with any comprehensive reply. But I think this issue is serious because the choice for the Australian people at the next election will never have been so stark now that the Opposition has finally laid down its marvellous new consumption tax. The lines are tightly drawn and we look forward to the fight. As I said, we are not going to transform the Parliament into a debating society for the deluded people opposite. The whole case for a consumption tax rests and falls on the economic need for it. Just by one test, the tax cuts proposed by the Opposition are almost paid for with expenditure cuts, so by definition there is no need for a consumption tax; all the rest of it is a blind, a hoax.

This massive document is just a bulky election manifesto. It has 19 chapters in 345 pages. It is supplemented by nine supporting papers in another 243 pages. It comes complete with a 67-page executive summary—all in all, about 655 pages. It is incomprehensible to the average Australian.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you read them all?

—I doubt the back bench of the Opposition has read it. In spite of its bulk, it makes absolutely no sense. It is a monumental hoax. It purports to spell out what is wrong with the Australian economy and how the coalition would allegedly go about fixing it. But it does not do this. Nowhere in the document does the coalition even attempt to seriously diagnose the problems which face the Australian economy. For example, it asserts that the fundamental problems are high inflation and poor trading performance. But nowhere in the 655 pages does it even attempt to seriously explain what causes these problems to emerge. Nowhere in the document does it even speculate about what are the important causes of inflation in modern open economies. Nowhere in the document does it even attempt to grapple with the determinants of modern industrial structures in our economy and the economies of those with whom we must trade. Nowhere in the document does it confront the complexity of modern international trading arrangements and processes which we face in our striving for better net export performance.

PARA.TAB: Yet, in spite of the absence of even an attempt at genuine diagnosis of our problems, it asserts that the cure is simple. It involves the typical monetarist medicine; that is, dismantling the welfare state, replacing much of the present tax system with a regressive indirect tax on consumption, and using monetarist policies to achieve a targeted nought to 2 per cent inflation.

How can the coalition expect the Australian people to take it seriously when it so vehemently advocates the cure without bothering to even attempt a serious diagnosis of the problem? The Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) is a doctor of extremely dubious practice. Would honourable members trust this professional approach to looking after their own health? Would they be comfortable allowing such a doctor to look after the nation's health service? Indeed, will the Australian people trust such shabby professionalism to exercise control over the whole economy? The answer is a categorical no. By the time the Government has finished taking this document apart—argument by argument, paragraph by paragraph—there will be nothing left except a heap of ruined political aspirations on the Opposition's side of the House.

Indeed, we are thankful to the Opposition for finally coming clean with its policy agenda. We have certainly waited long enough. But what an anticlimax. By the time we are finished with this document the people of Australia will be in no doubt about why the coalition has been in opposition for the majority of the past decade and will remain in opposition until it decides to get a leader who has the ability and the nerve to drag its thinking into the twentieth century.

The coalition's Fightback document is nothing but a hoax. It does not even attempt to solve the problems which confront us. It is nothing other than a veiled and sinister attempt to undermine just about everything that this Government has worked towards during the past nine years.

The hidden agenda which pervades it is the dismantling of the Australian economic and social system as we know it. It aims to replace it with an economy which is driven by greed, which benefits the wealthy and which condemns ordinary Australians to ever-declining relative shares of the national cake. It is nothing other than the tried and failed policies of Thatcher and Reagan. In other words, it is a dog's breakfast scraped from the tables of Thatcher and Reagan.

These monetarist policies have resulted in the fiscal blowout and poor trading performance in the United States. The same policies have also led to the severe de-industrialisation and poor trading performance of today's British economy, together with the polarisation of British society into the haves and the have-nots. We do not want that kind of society in Australia. The United Kingdom has a big value added tax and it has a big recession. So why does this magic cure not solve Britain's problems?

The Fightback document is full of naive, glib and downright false statements about the sanctity of uncontrolled markets and how perfect competition can deliver optimal economic, social and ethical outcomes. It could not have been written by anyone who has even the most basic understanding of the workings of modern complex economies. We know that the Leader of the Opposition has some knowledge of economics. He is not knowing about politics and is either not knowing or cynical about how modern real world economies work. We know he knows something of the naive computer simulated models of fictitious idealised economies when he gets out his outdated textbooks.

The document also shows that the Leader of the Opposition is not alone in this regard within the coalition. Given that it is allegedly a team effort, it demonstrates that there is not one person amongst opposition members who have the ability to form even the most basic grasp of how modern real world economies and markets operate.

Many of the proposals would worsen the problems which our economy faces rather than solving them. I can just take the first example. The document points to inflation as being one of the economy's major ills. I agree that inflation undermines the competitive performance of the economy and redistributes income and wealth from the poor to the rich. It is for this reason that the Government has worked to reduce inflation to the record lows we have achieved today.

However, while we understand the cause of inflation and the need for control, nowhere in the Opposition's document does it even attempt to grapple with the underlying causes of inflation; nor does it show any understanding of how to control inflation. Nowhere does it recognise that a proportion of Australia's inflation is imported because of the openness of the economy. Rather, its solution is to commit monetary policy to a target inflation of nought to 2 per cent.

This is done without any recognition of what world inflation may do. This is done with virtually no recognition of what members of the Opposition's own inflation would do and the timing of that on the imposition of a consumption tax if they were to get government. The only way this can be achieved is by severe monetary contraction together with unprecedented high interest rates. That is the only way we could get nought to 2 per cent.
This would cause investment to collapse, GDP growth to halt, unemployment to rise further and it would worsen Australia's ability to compete in foreign markets in the long term.

Any possible gains to families due to the tax cuts would be wiped out by a multiple factor. The document is unethical because it attempts to hide this policy prescription. Nowhere does the document attempt to spell out the consequences of interest rate movements for wiping out the tax cut benefits.

I give a second example. The leaders of the Opposition have committed themselves to extremely tight fiscal policies. They have accompanied this with a so-called guarantee that the GST would not rise above 15 per cent. This guarantee is worthless. Who cares if the Leader of the Opposition and the Leader of the National Party resign? Once the GST was legislated into place, others could and would easily raise the rate.

The international evidence supports this. For example, from a man named Tait of the International Monetary Fund, if we look at the original GST rates and the present rates we see the following: Austria, 8 to 20 per cent; Belgium, 18 to 19 per cent; Denmark, 10 to 22 per cent; France, 13.6 to 18.6 per cent; Germany, 10 to 14 per cent; Ireland, 16.37 to 21 per cent; Israel, 8 to 16 per cent; Italy, 12 to 19 per cent; Luxembourg, 8 to 12 per cent; Madagascar, 12 to 15 per cent; Netherlands, 12 to 18.5 per cent; New Zealand, 10 to 12.5 per cent; Portugal, 16 to 17 per cent; United Kingdom, 10 to 17.5 per cent; and Uruguay, 14 to 22 per cent. The United States does not have one.

In the interim, however, with less direct tax revenues, handing tax powers to the States, tight expenditure plans and an immovable GST rate, the scope and power of fiscal policy would be totally evaporated. All macro-economic management would therefore be forced permanently onto tight monetary policy and high interest rates.

The third example is: one of the fundamental arguments in the Opposition's election manifesto is that the move to a GST will improve the international competitiveness of the Australian economy and improve trading performance. This is wrong. This argument could not have been made by anyone who has conducted a cursory examination of available knowledge.

If we talk to Professor Feldstein, a former President of the US Council of Economic Advisers, and Professor Paul Krugman who is one of the foremost authorities on modern trade theory, we find that they have formally demonstrated that a GST will not improve trade performance, and will probably worsen it in the medium to long term.

In a pure GST model with all goods included the effect of international trading performance in an economy with a floating exchange rate like Australia will be zero because the exchange rates will adjust. In a more realistic model in which some goods, such as housing and personal services for example, are exempted, the GST will raise the price of tradeables relative to nontradeables and induce a substitution of these services for tradeable goods. The most likely effect in this case is decline in exports.

The fourth example is: the Fightback document shows a complete absence of any awareness of political processes. Many of the policies would result in severe industrial disruption which would negate and prevent any positive outcome. It is simply wrong to advance naive policies without any consideration of the political process through which they may be implemented.

I turn to the fifth example. The basis for the policy package is a computer simulated model which is entirely incapable of modelling how the economy might respond to the proposals. For example, the scenario C simulation which drives the Fightback package, models the entire gamut of so-called micro-reforms by simply changing upwards a single figure for productivity. This is totally ad hoc and indefensible on three grounds. First, there is no way of telling how much productivity will change, let alone whether it will rise. Second, this analysis is incapable of dealing with the processes through which such changes are introduced. Third, other parameters in the model would change in response to such a policy shift. Together these points render the analysis useless.

Australia's fundamental trading problem is recurrent terms of trade turnarounds like 1985-86 and now, and corrupted world markets for our primary product and resource based trade. But we are turning this picture around. (Time expired)
