DEBATE.TITLE: FEDERAL COURT OF AUSTRALIA AMENDMENT BILL 1991

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 13 November, on motion by Mr Duffy:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Costello Mr P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Federal Court of Australia Amendment Bill 1991 is bad legislation. The Opposition will vote against it. The proposals contained in this Bill are an attack on the way legal rights have been traditionally exercised under our system of law. Under our system of law, individual rights are exercised by individual choice. Individual rights are exercised on behalf of individuals who choose to take their claims to court.

PARA.TAB: Firstly, under the proposals in this Bill individual rights will be exercised on behalf of individuals thrown into classes at the choice of people who decide to initiate class actions. The Bill is flawed because it is an attack on the way legal rights are traditionally exercised in this country.

Secondly, this Bill is a step on the way to making Australia a more litigious society. It will encourage the proliferation of litigation in this country and it will encourage the proliferation of lawsuits in this country, and that is not in the interests of the public in the long term.

Thirdly, the Bill is flawed because it will change the nature of legal practice. Hitherto, lawyers have provided services to those wanting to exercise their legal rights, who consult them and ask those lawyers to act on their behalf. This will change with the introduction of the alterations proposed in this Bill. Lawyers will be encouraged to commence entrepreneurial practice, to find people to initiate class actions, and to litigate those actions through individuals on behalf of classes. Lawyers will have an incentive to spruik for actions on behalf of people who do not know the action is being brought, who have not consulted the lawyer to bring the action, and who may not even want the action to be brought on their behalf.

Fourthly, this is flawed legislation because no grounds have been shown which will justify the changes introduced by this Bill. If the object is to reduce the costs of litigation, the proposals in this Bill are a wholly unnecessary overreaction. There is no correspondence between the problem of the costs of litigation and the solution mooted in this Bill. It is like having open-heart surgery to treat a headache. It is an unnecessary overreaction. During the committee stage of this Bill, the Opposition will move amendments which provide a workable and sensible solution, which provide proportionate surgery for the malady which is to be cured, and which meet the real problems of the costs of litigation without the detrimental effects inherent in this Bill.

Let me briefly outline what this Bill does. It proposes to insert a new part IVA into the Federal Court of Australia Act. It will enable the bringing of class actions in the court. The Federal Court rules currently make provision for numerous persons with the same interest to bring an action in the name of one person representing the others. There is current provision in the Federal Court rules to bring representative proceedings. Recently this was done in a case in which His Honour Mr Justice Wilcox was presiding, where 116 people were allowed to group their claim into one proceeding and have it proceed under the current rules in the Federal Court.

But this Bill proposes to introduce a new part. Under the proposed section 33C, seven or more persons may have an action commenced on their behalf by a representative party where the claims are in respect of or arise out of the same, similar or related circumstances and where the claims give rise to a substantial common issue of law or fact. The proceeding may be commenced whether or not it is concerned with separate contracts or transactions, or involves separate acts or omissions. The consent of a person to be grouped into the class is not required. A representative party can start an action on behalf of a class without the person's consent, if that person is a member of the class—except where the person is the Commonwealth, a Minister, a body corporate established for a public purpose, or an officer of the Commonwealth or a State.

Representative proceedings may not be commenced if the proceedings would be concerned only with claims where the Federal Court has jurisdiction solely by reason of cross-vesting. But since the Federal Court has an associated jurisdiction, this Bill will open the procedure to claims which primarily relate to State law where there is an associated Federal element.

The new part is supposed to apply only to causes of action arising after the commencement of this legislation. But this does not mean it will apply only to transactions occurring after the commencement of the Act. Suppose, for example, a claim for product liability is made. Even if the product has already been sold, if the loss arises after the commencement of the Act the cause of action would accrue after commencement and the procedure would be open in respect of that particular claim.

A group member may opt out of a representative proceeding or class action by written notice given under the rules of the court. Notice must be given to group members of the commencement of the proceeding. The court may not order the notice to be given personally to each group member unless it is satisfied that it is reasonably practicable and not unduly expensive to do so. It is plainly intended that notice of proceedings be given by press advertisement or radio or television broadcast. That means that somebody can commence an action, and the court will order that notice through press advertisement or radio broadcasting be given that it has commenced. Unless members of the class give notice to the court and opt out of that proceeding, their rights will be litigated as part of that action.

The court can order that the representative proceeding not continue where it concludes that if judgment were given in favour of the action the cost of identifying group members and distributing to them would be excessive. The court can order a representative proceeding not continue if costs are likely to exceed the cost of individual separate proceedings. The plain intention is that individuals' rights be bound up in a class action and determined as a class. Where the court determines to award damages, it can do so in a way that the entitlement of each member is worked out in relation to directions to be given by the court. The court can set up a fund to hold moneys to be distributed, and the costs of administering the fund are borne by the fund.

No rules as to the award of costs in representative proceedings are introduced, except as provided in section 33ZJ. It is assumed, therefore, that costs will follow the ordinary rules. If the person bringing the action on behalf of the class loses the action, that person would be liable. If the person wins, that person will be entitled to costs. But there is no provision in the Act for the person who is the representative party and who may be liable under an award of costs to get a contribution from the members of the class. This means that if a respondent wins an action and gets an award of costs and the representative party is impecunious—even though there might be a lot of assets held by the class collectively—there will be no access to those particular costs. Indeed, there is no provision in this Bill for the awarding of security for costs in respect of a representative party bringing the action.

The Bill, even as it is drawn, leaves many unanswered questions. It does have an element of retrospectivity, allowing claims to be brought under this procedure where transactions giving rise to the claim have already occurred—such as the purchase of a product, as I have already outlined—if the loss occurs after the commencement of the Bill. If the loss occurs after the commencement of the Bill, the representative party could bring the action, and bring it on behalf of all the class that was in that particular situation.

So notwithstanding the assurances that have been given by the responsible Minister in the other place, Senator Tate, it does have an element of retrospectivity. Also, it does not make clear how costs are to be apportioned amongst group members for unsuccessful claims. As I have already outlined, it is to be assumed that costs will fall on the representative party. This means that if one is going to bring a class action, one would be wise to choose an impecunious representative party. If the claim should fail and an award of costs is made against the applicant, the applicant will have no assets from which to pay the costs. This will also lead to the practice of `greenmail', whereby actions are commenced against respondents and the respondents know that the costs of defending the action are so high that it is commercial commonsense to pay out the claim rather than have it effectively litigated, particularly when there is no guarantee that, even if an award of costs is made, costs will be recoverable from the representative party.

The Bill also alters the normal rules in relation to the limitation of actions. The limitation period ceases whilst a person is a member of a class and the class action is proceeding. When that person takes himself out of the class the limitation period starts to run again. It is feasible that a person could be a member of a class for six or seven years whilst the action was proceeding, pull himself out and effectively commence his own action which would be outside the normal limitation period but inside the limitation period as altered by the proposals in this Bill.

The Bill is also defective because it makes no provision for cross claims. It does not explain how cross claims will be brought against individual members of the class. It is obviously going to be very difficult to have cross claims against the representative party when the transactions, the facts and the circumstances could be very different in relation to each individual.

All of those defects, even on the face of the Government's own Bill, prove that this has not been well thought out. It is not a comprehensive code. It is not something that will give certainty to the way in which proceedings will go ahead in the Federal Court if this Bill is passed.

Leaving aside all the defects in the way the Government has put forward its own proposal or its own model, the proposal is fundamentally flawed. As I said earlier, firstly, it is an attack on the way legal rights have been traditionally exercised under our system of law. Under our system of law a person who is aggrieved has the right to approach the court at his choice and to have that grievance heard. He decides whether to lodge a claim. He does not have his claim lodged by someone else without his consent and without his knowledge. This will become possible under this Bill.

Unless a person tells the court that he does not want his claim litigated, he will have his claim litigated as part of a class whether he likes it or not and whether he knows about it or not and his individual rights will be subsumed into the rights of the class. If the action is mucked up and if the action loses, he will have no right to come back and have his individual claim heard at his option by his lawyer presenting his evidence as he sees fit. Rights can be extinguished without the knowledge of a person who is a member of a class. They can be extinguished unless that person knows and opts out of the particular proposal.

The Business Council of Australia recently put out a press release. It has sought and received comments from leading firms of solicitors in relation to this particular proposal. Mr Wilson, from the firm Clayton Utz, said:

SPEECH.PARA: A person who fails to have the capacity to take a positive step to opt out of a representative action will automatically become a member of the class and will thereby become bound by the decision in the representative action. If the plaintiffs obtain a favourable result there may be no prejudice but if the plaintiffs fail it means that a person who has taken no positive step in either identifying himself or putting forward his claim will be bound by the adverse decision of the Court.
This appears to us to be neither equitable nor efficient.
Professor Bob Baxt, from the firm Arthur Robinson and Hedderwicks, said much the same thing:

The opt out system is another example of increasing interference with the individual rights of citizens. They should not be joined or named in a particular proceeding unless they provide their consent. Whilst they may not be named in the proceedings, it is possible that they will be named (without their knowledge), thus impinging on their right to privacy. In a democratic society citizens should be able to choose whether they want to be involved in particular litigation or proceedings. They should not have to go to court to assert this fundamental right.

The amendments which the Opposition will move during the committee stage reinforce the traditional rights of the individual in relation to litigation. They will provide a mechanism which will save costs and provide economies of scale, but preserve individual rights. One can choose to have one's rights litigated rather than have them litigated by somebody else.

PARA.TAB: Secondly, I said that this Bill is a step on the way to making Australia a more litigious society. For many there is a belief that life's problems can all be solved by legal actions, that there is compensation out there for wrongs and if we can only find the defendant and find the class, all of life's problems will go away. This Bill re-emphasises and underlines that basic wrong belief about the way in which society works. It says that any person who can be slotted into a class, and a defendant conveniently found, can be given compensation. This Bill provides a mechanism by which that fundamentally wrong view of the way in which society works can be facilitated.

I am disappointed that some of the support for this move comes from the organised consumer movement. Honourable members should not believe that the promotion of a litigious society is in the best interests of consumers. It is in the interests of lawyers—the Labor Party loves lawyers; it keeps on introducing more mechanisms by which lawyers can make money—but honourable members should not believe for a moment that it is in the interests of consumers. Higher risks of litigation on a wider scale mean higher premiums, higher costs and higher prices. That is not in the interests of consumers.

Sometimes people confuse anti-business legislation as being pro-consumer legislation. That is not necessarily the case. This is a classic piece of legislation which Senator Peter Walsh would describe as new class legislation designed to provide income for the new class, including lawyers, who will profit greatly out of this. But honourable members should not believe that it will help consumers.

The time has come in Australia where we ought to be encouraging business, not increasing opportunities for organised litigation against it. Make no mistake about it, this Bill has the potential to encourage litigation. It will encourage widespread organised litigation on behalf of classes.

I recommend that honourable members read the book, The Litigation Explosion—What Happened when America Unleashed the Lawsuit. America unleashed the lawsuit primarily through class actions. There are additional features of the American system that help organised litigation, such as the costs rule and contingency fees, but the first breakthrough in relation to organised litigation in the United States was in relation to class actions. Let me tell honourable members how it works. The book states:

SPEECH.PARA: After the brouhaha over the liaison between evangelist Jim Bakker and church secretary Jessica Hahn, lawyers filed suit against the Bakker ministry on behalf of three members of an Ohio family who had given the ministry $11,800.

They also filed on behalf of the whole class of donors. The lawyers asked for $100m in compensatory damages for the whole class and $500m in punitive damages. That gives us an idea that when a client goes to a lawyer with a claim, the lawyer will not just issue the proceeding on that client's behalf, he will issue the proceeding on behalf of the whole class that that client can be part of and he can escalate the damages in the claim and escalate the fees. Let me give honourable members another example of how it works in the United States. The book goes on:

After a 1987 Northwest crash in Detroit, one enterprising runner reportedly dressed as a priest to mingle among grieving families. Others posed as Red Cross workers after a store roof collapsed in south Texas, helping dig out victims and sign them up.

This will promote a more litigious society. Any lawyer who finds a client who has a claim would be mad just to issue the claim on behalf of that client. What he will do now is issue the claim on behalf of the class that that client falls into. This is why I said, thirdly, that the Bill changes the nature of legal practice. A lawyer will no longer be acting for a client he knows who wants him to act on his or her behalf, he can turn the suit into a class action and act on behalf of the class as long as he can find somebody who has a valid claim. This point is also made by some of the country's leading solicitors. Mr Salgo from Baker and McKenzie stated:

In our view the existence of an opt out procedure will often lead to the institution of law suits, nominally on behalf of a large class composed of unidentified individuals, but which might in reality be conducted for the benefit of a small group of lawyers and their associates, substantially motivated by self interest. Such proceedings would be driven by those running them as opposed to the client group. We believe that this fairly summarises the United States experience with opt out procedures.

That is the way it will work. If a lawyer finds a client who has suffered injuries from a damaged toaster, he does not sue on behalf of that client, he will sue on behalf of all purchasers of that particular toaster. Of course, if a lawyer finds a person who has bought a damaged toaster and another lawyer finds another person who has bought a damaged toaster, each can commence a class action on behalf of all toaster buyers and the court, presumably, will have to decide which one of the actions goes forward as a class action.

PARA.TAB: In reality, the court will decide which group of lawyers will get the proceeds of running the class action. We will have entrepreneurial lawyers finding plaintiffs, turning them into class actions and basically fighting over the pickings. My press release states:

SPEECH.PARA: Class actions will also facilitate the emergence of entrepreneurial lawyers more interested in getting control of litigation on behalf of large classes than in representing individual clients. Such lawyers would spruik for legal actions. Different firms will chase individuals to initiate class actions so that the firms get control of the legal proceedings and the fees they will generate. The Court will be faced with having to choose between different class representatives being put forward in the knowledge they are being forced to decide which lawyers will take the fruits of handling the action.

That is how there will be conflicts of interest. As lawyers fight over who gets the right to represent the class, they will be fighting over who gets the right to run the action and who gets the right to make the money. The primary interest of the lawyers will be to control the litigation rather than to service their clients. This is another factor which will prompt the explosion in litigation as a result of these wholly unnecessary amendments.

PARA.TAB: If the Government really wanted to promote economies of scale and avoid a multiplicity of separate actions, those people who wanted to join an action could be given the right to opt in to that action. They could go down to the court or write to the court and say that they wanted part of the action and wanted to have their individual rights litigated in the action and to individually choose to exercise their rights, rather than have those rights exercised for them as part of a class action by failing to opt out.

If the Government really wanted to take advantage of those economies of scale it could vote for our amendments. Our amendments would harmonise the Federal Court procedure with the procedures in State courts, and particularly with the procedure which has recently been adopted in the Supreme Court of Victoria, which is essentially an opt-in system—a system which is consonant with the traditional exercise of individual rights and the way our legal system operates; a system which is not an unnecessary inducement or incitement to litigation; a system which will not encourage the emergence of entrepreneurial lawyers looking out for their own actions, putting them into a conflict of interest situation; and a system which would promote an outcome which would ameliorate the costs of justice.

The Government should have allowed proper time for the consideration of this proposal. The Government is trying to rush this proposal through before people become aware of the implications. It saw what happened when it exposed the product liability reforms for public debate. The response was overwhelming and it was forced to back down. It is not going to make that mistake again. The Government is trying to railroad this legislation through the Senate and the House of Representatives as fast as it can.
In a media statement put out on behalf of the Business Council of Australia on 25 November 1991, the Chairman of its Business Law and Regulation Panel, Mr Hugh Morgan, stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The disturbing feature of the Bill. . . is that there has been very little public debate about its implications, which are only now being understood.

He called on the Government to defer further consideration until it has an opportunity to consider fully the concerns expressed by law firms, as contained in his statement, some of which I have referred to in my speech.

PARA.TAB: The Government ought to allow the public to know what is in this Bill; it ought to allow sufficient consultation before moving on it; it ought to give the public time to become acquainted with the proposals; and it ought to see whether there is any genuine support amongst the public—not in organised consumer groups—for what can only be described as a move towards LA Law-style litigation. If the Government cannot do that, it should accept amendments that we will move in the committee stage to introduce a sane, moderate proposal which has all the benefits that the Government, supposedly, is trying to direct itself to, with none of the unfortunate detriments which will come about as a result of this Bill.

Senator Tate is determined to steer a narrow line. He feels that he cannot antagonise people who have been agitating for this over a long period. He thinks that he has found a way through it. He has not. He is bringing in a half-baked proposal which does not just address the identified problems but goes much further. It has a real risk for the way in which litigation will be conducted in Australia, which is wrong, flawed, and ought not be proceeded with. If the Government cannot wait for the public to become acquainted and let its views be known on this proposal, it ought to vote for the amendments which I will move in the committee stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duncan The Hon P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am delighted to support the Federal Court of Australia Amendment Bill 1991, which I believe is one of the most important pieces of legislation that has been introduced into this Parliament by this Government. This legislation seeks to redress the imbalance in the court system, in the legal system, between the people who are wealthy and powerful and those who are less wealthy and less powerful—the poor, the ordinary people of this country. That is the basic intention of this legislation.

PARA.TAB: It arises from the 1988 report of the Law Reform Commission, which the Commission produced following a reference by Attorney-General Ellicott in 1977. The point I want to draw from that is that that is an indication to people of how much time and effort went into the careful preparation of the report of the Law Reform Commission which finally led to this legislation. For anybody to say, as the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Costello) did just before the suspension of the sitting for dinner, that this legislation has been rushed into the Parliament and that the Government is in some haste to get it through indicates that that person is not taking the matter seriously. This matter was first put before the Law Reform Commission in 1977.

I am particularly interested in this matter because it is of concern to anybody who believes in equity and a fair go in our society, and that ordinary people should be able to get remedies in the courts. Whilst people can say, rather facetiously, that any individual who has a right can exercise that right, we know that that is not the reality; the reality is that ordinary people, as consumers or injured workers, for example, are not able to exercise their rights in the courts as more well-to-do people are able to.

This legislation seeks to enable those people who have a common cause of action to club together so that they are able to have a matter litigated and, hopefully, result in a satisfactory outcome. I have noticed from reading some of the Senate Hansard reports on this matter that there have not been very clear examples of what the legislation is trying to achieve. I thought I would give an example that came to my attention some years ago. At that time a company that produced car tyres in this country had produced a large number of faulty tyres. The fault was that the tyres were not matured properly, I think was the term. The result was that people who bought them new would not notice that there was anything wrong with them, but they would get only 15,000 kilometres from the tyres before they were worn out.

It was only after a large number of complaints that the company finally started to agree that there might have been something wrong with the product and replaced the tyres. However, thousands of people who had bought the tyres never became aware that there was anything wrong with them; they simply thought the tyres had worn out pretty quickly and replaced them, purchasing new tyres.

Had a so-called class action been available, an action could have been taken on behalf of all of those people and the company could have been sued. Even though each individual person might have had a claim for only $30 or $40, the company would have had to notify the names of those who had purchased those tyres and it would have been possible for the plaintiff to get onto all of those people and to draw them into the action so that they would have been able to get redress and proper compensation for the loss that they suffered. That is the way in which this legislation will work in the future.

I want to say that the Law Reform Commission did an excellent job in preparing its forty-sixth report. It is an exceptionally good report. It is a scholarly report. I congratulate all the people who worked on it—there were a large number of people and I will not name them now—and who did a thoroughly good job. I also want to congratulate the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs (Senator Tate) on bringing the legislation forward. It was obvious that it would draw some

SPEECH.PARA: controversy, as it has. However, he was prepared to pick up the ball and run with it. I congratulate him on that. In years to come when ordinary people are benefiting from this legislation, they might not go to Senator Tate and say, `Thank you very much', but he will know that it was his legislation which led to a fairer go for thousands and thousands of ordinary Australians.

PARA.TAB: The honourable member for Higgins had a lot to say in condemning this legislation and trying to draw comparisons with the legislation that exists in the United States for class actions. That is a completely fallacious comparison. There is one significant difference between the class action proposal in this legislation and the legislation which exists in the United States. That is to do with the way in which lawyers in the United States go about their business.

There are arrangements in the US by which lawyers can charge on an ad valorem scale, or charge so-called contingency fees, so that a lawyer can enter a contract with individual plaintiffs to take one-third of the proceeds for damages of a successful claim. We do not have that arrangement in Australia, so there is nothing like that sort of inducement to lawyers to actually seek clients and take actions.

I think the scares referred to by the honourable member for Higgins are wholly unfounded in the Australian context. I think it was quite unfair of him to raise the matter in the way in which he did, because in Australia we simply are not going to see a rush to law as a result of this legislation. On the contrary, this legislation may turn out to be part of the micro-economic reform strategy of the Government.

We can see from some examples of the extraordinarily inefficient proceedings that have been taken in the courts in the past that this legislation may lead to greater efficiency. For example, more than 300 workers were afflicted with asbestos related disease as a result of working for a CSR subsidiary, Midalco, in Western Australia. The result was that 300 people took actions in the courts, claiming damages. If this legislation had been in place, all of them may have been able to take one simple action; in doing that, there would have been one court case—possibly a more complex case than the 300 individual cases, but the amount of court time would have been divided by almost 300. I think that is a great example of why we need this legislation and why as a Parliament we should adopt it.

I think it is a great pity that the Liberal Opposition has chosen to oppose this legislation. That shows how far it has moved towards the extreme right in the past decade or so. I remind the House that it was Attorney-General Ellicott in the Fraser Government who referred these matters to the Law Reform Commission; a Liberal Attorney-General wanted to see law reform on the issue of class action. The Law Reform Commission laboured hard and produced its report. What do we find? As I see it, the Minister for Justice, Senator Tate, has not picked up the whole of the report, only the essentials of it. Even then, the Liberals are opposing it.

The Opposition has opposed the legislation. Why? Anyone who listened, as I did, to the contribution from the honourable member for Higgins could get some idea of why the Opposition would be opposing it. The honourable member spent most of his speech quoting and requoting from the Business Council of Australia's press release which was put out with a series of quotes from Mr Hugh Morgan. It is interesting to look through that press release and deal with some of the comments that were made. Strangely, all of the law firms that were quoted as having concerns about and opposition to this legislation were the big corporate law firms of the nation. That is hardly surprising, because their clients—the big firms, manufacturers and the like—are the ones who put unsafe products onto the market in Australia from time to time, the ones who are involved in unsafe work practices, and who undertake various other activities which lay them open to action in the courts.

In the past these wrongdoers have often got away with doing that because it has been almost impossible for the man in the street to sue huge corporations. The honourable member for Higgins said that this legislation will lead to increases in costs. I say that, if these firms are acting wrongly, they ought to be brought to book. The way to do that is to ensure that they can be properly taken before the appropriate court and dealt with. This legislation will enable that to happen, at least in the Federal Court.

It is interesting to note Clayton Utz's comment in the press release from the Business Council of Australia that clause 332(4) would lead to injustice. That clause does not mean what Clayton Utz says it does. It enables the court to give directions in those cases, but not all cases, where individual group members need to show that they belong to a group. I see nothing wrong with putting the power to do that into the hands of the Federal Court. Saying that should not happen is really an expression of a lack of confidence in the Federal Court. Baker and McKenzie made the following comment:

SPEECH.PARA: In our view the existence of an opt out procedure will often lead to the institution of law suits, nominally on behalf of a large class composed of unidentified individuals, but which might in reality be conducted for the benefit of a small group of lawyers and their associates, substantially motivated by self interest.

Coming from an organisation such as Baker and McKenzie, I think that comment must almost be tongue in cheek. However, it is fair to say that that comment might be true in some US class actions, for the reasons that I have referred to earlier about contingency fees. But this Bill does not introduce the US system, and I would not support the introduction of the US system. No contingency fees or other cost incentives for lawyers are contained in this Bill, so this comment has no relevance to the Bill.

PARA.TAB: I said a moment ago that this law will apply only to the Federal Court of Australia. I think that is inevitable, but I think it is a sad commentary that the law will not apply at this stage to the cross-vesting jurisdiction of the Federal Court. I hope that in the future the Government will look at an amendment to the Bill—or the Act, as I hope it will be—which will allow the cross-vesting jurisdiction to be taken into account for this Act, particularly in relation to States where the supreme courts already have a class action procedure, such as South Australia. There seems to me to be no reason why South Australia should not have its cross-vesting jurisdiction included in this legislation; likewise with the Victorians and any other State that chooses to pick up this type of legislation and run with it.

I do not know who in the Office of Parliamentary Counsel drafted this legislation, but I want to compliment them. I hope that this Bill indicates a new style of drafting at the Commonwealth level. It is clean and understandable, and a reasonably intelligent lay person would be able to read this Bill and understand what it is about. I think that is an enormous advance on the sort of drafting that we so often get at the Commonwealth level.

I have made this point before and will make it again: it is strange that the High Court manages to interpret the legislation from South Australia, Tasmania, Western Australia, Victoria and Queensland, where the style is quite simple, and, on the other hand, manages to interpret the legislation from New South Wales and the Commonwealth, which is of much greater complexity. If the High Court can do that, I cannot see the reason for the continuation of the complex type of drafting that we so often see in this place. The Commonwealth drafting people should concentrate on placing more emphasis on plain English and explanations in legislation which are readily interpretable by, as I have said, intelligent lay people. That would be very useful.
In conclusion, as I am out of time, I support the legislation; I think it is long overdue. I will be delighted to see it become law, and I congratulate the Minister for Justice on bringing it in.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrews Mr K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I once belonged to a book club which was run in such a way that, unless I sent back the monthly form to indicate a lack of interest in the book of the month, I received the book with a bill forthwith. If I happened to be away or to have forgotten to post back the form, it became a devil of a job to return the book at my expense. On one occasion the book went astray, and months later the book club was still trying to dun me for payment for something I did not need, did not want and that in fact had gone astray. I tell this story by way of warning because the Federal Court of Australia Amendment Bill operates on the same principle but it has much greater and more serious repercussions for the Australian people. It follows a passable theory in practice, but in reality it is another thing.

PARA.TAB: The central feature of this Bill is a procedure which allows a small group of people to commence and settle legal actions on behalf of a class of individuals without the consent of those individuals who are then bound by the court's procedure unless they opt out of the proceedings. As has already been indicated in the debate in this House, the origin of this Bill lies in the 1988 report of the Australian Law Reform Commission entitled Grouped Proceedings in the Federal Court. The Commission was given terms of reference on 1 February 1977 by the then Attorney-General, the Hon. R.J. Ellicott, QC.

Although the Commission ultimately, 11 years later—in 1988—favoured the grouped proceedings and the implementation of a procedure by which individuals could be included in a group for the purposes of litigation, under the opt-out legislation the choice between opting into a suit and opting out of a suit was in contention throughout the inquiry, and it is still a matter of contention even today.

It should be reiterated that the coalition is not opposed to the concept of grouped proceedings but it does have objections to the opt-out model which has been favoured by the Government. We believe that an opt-in model, whereby a proposal to bring a legal action on behalf of a group and not just an individual may be advertised and individuals invited to join in those proceedings, is preferable to the system which is contemplated in this Bill. It is true that the opt-out model has been favoured in the United States of America in various jurisdictions but, equally, it has been rejected in the European court system.

I shall not repeat the arguments which have been advanced by the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Costello) against the opt-out system and in favour of the opt-in alternatives, but I do wish to address a few remarks to a number of practical consequences of this legislation. It is interesting to note that the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs, Senator Tate, said in a media release dated 17 April 1991:

SPEECH.PARA: The legislation will confer no new legal rights—but it will allow people to assert existing rights collectively, effectively and more cheaply. If such a measure had already been in operation, the present actions by haemophiliacs and others who have medically acquired AIDS, for example, could have proceeded with one action representing the general group of AIDS sufferers.

It is also interesting to note, in the light of the reported comments of Senator Tate, the comments of Mr Peter Gordon, a solicitor representing sufferers of medically acquired AIDS, that this legislation would not assist those suffering from the condition.

PARA.TAB: The honourable member for Makin (Mr Duncan) has made some derogatory comments about legal firms that have offered their professional opinion about this legislation, suggesting that they were from a conservative mould. May I remind the honourable member for Makin that the firm from which Mr Peter Gordon comes, namely Slater and Gordon in Melbourne, is well known as a labour firm and not one which has been traditionally associated with representing employers. Mr Gordon said:

SPEECH.PARA: The proponents of class actions need to understand that there are tremendous liability differences across a class of victims. If the first case for medically acquired HIV brought in Australia had been the representative case everyone would have lost.
Mr Gordon said that the class actions do not achieve justice in AIDS actions:

. . . because if you simply try to assign the result in one case to every case that would be unjust. On the other hand, if you tried within the scope of one class action to solve every single legal issue it would be an impossible job and it would probably cost more in legal costs than running all of the claims individually.

Mr Gordon went on to say that it would be of assistance to HIV sufferers if the Federal Government stopped trying to get the States not to deal with AIDS sufferers for compensation. In fact, a survey of the States in these cases shows that, given the alleged objective of this Bill to assist groups ranging from small shareholders and investors to people pursuing medical or consumer claims, there is rampant hypocrisy on the part of the Government. For example, the current Government has done nothing to assist the speedy resolution of the claims of those persons suffering from AIDS as a result of alleged medical negligence.

PARA.TAB: There are approximately 200 people around Australia with medically acquired AIDS. Only in Western Australia has the Government been prepared to settle these actions. In other States we have the spectre of long, costly trials. AIDS is not the only grim reaper; the Federal Government, in denying the claims of AIDS sufferers with medically acquired AIDS, is itself in these instances also a grim reaper.

In the most recent trial in Victoria it has been estimated that the State's legal costs alone in an 87-day trial were some $10m. Yet I am informed that many if not all these cases could be settled and that the State governments not only in Victoria but in other States of Australia are willing to settle them. Why then, in the face of this legislation which has the aim of improving access to the legal system and presumably the delivery of justice, is the Federal Government blocking the settlement of these cases? For $10m in legal fees—that is the cost of the legal fees in just one case—20 of these cases could probably be settled. The financial savings to the Commonwealth and the States would be enormous.

In fact, the only reason that has been advanced against settlement of the cases involving AIDS sufferers is that the AIDS sufferers should not be differentiated because of the cause of their disease. The consequence is that those who acquired the disease medically through the provable negligence of public institutions and government instrumentalities are being denied compensation simply because some Ministers in this Government do not wish to offend interest groups concerned with the protection of people who have acquired the disease by sexual transmission and who are overwhelmingly, in this country, homosexual.

It is not a question of innocence or guilt. These people received a terminal disease directly from a government instrumentality or an organisation directly funded by government and, therefore, there is some responsibility towards them in relation to their sickness and the care of their health condition. What we are talking about is dealing with institutions which, once the nature of the threat of AIDS was known, exposed patients unnecessarily to risk through blood products that had not been screened and did not warn those patients of the danger.

Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Hon. G.G.D. Scholes)—Order! Could I advise the honourable member that he is getting a long way away from the Bill. He quoted an example and he has now been speaking to that example for the best part of five minutes. It is not relevant to the Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will finish the example. It is an example quoted by the proposer of this Bill in the Senate, namely, Senator Tate, who said that this legislation—namely legislation to allow people to bring these sorts of cases—would enable sufferers, and he gave the example of AIDS cases, to settle their cases more effectively and with justice.
—I am aware of that. The honourable member, though, is debating the responsibilities, not the Bill.

—As Mr Deputy Speaker says, but it does indicate once again, I would suggest, the hypocrisy of a government. It says on one hand, `Let us have greater access to justice'. On the other hand, the settlement of 200 cases around Australia where access to justice could be determined quite quickly by the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services (Mr Howe) is, on the information that has been provided by Labor lawyers—not conservative lawyers—being held up. That is a blatant case of hypocrisy on the part of this Government.

PARA.TAB: Let me turn to something more apposite to the Bill itself, namely, the matter of costs. The matter of costs has been raised by the honourable member for Higgins in his contribution to the debate about this Bill. It is worth noting that the Law Reform Commission in the model draft Act which was appended to its report included the following proposition as section 31, subsection (1):

SPEECH.PARA: Subject to this Act, the court may not order a group member to pay the costs of the respondent in the group members proceeding (except to the extent that the group member has the conduct of proceedings) but such an order may be made against the principal applicant.
Subsection (2) said:

In a group members proceeding, an order for security for costs may not be made against the principal applicant on the ground that the proceeding is for the benefit of the group member and not for the benefit of the principal applicant.

In the draft explanatory memorandum set out in the Law Reform Commission's report No. 46 of 1988, the Commission indicated that proposed section 31(1) would relieve the group members from liability to pay the costs on the part of any other party and impose that liability on the principal applicant. The ordinary liability for costs would apply, however, to the extent that the group member was conducting his or her own proceeding. In paragraph 261 of the report the Law Reform Commission stated:

The principal applicant should be liable for any costs ordered to be paid in group members proceedings of which she or he has had the conduct. Group members should not be liable to pay the costs of another party except to the extent that they have assumed the conduct of their own proceedings. This should not preclude a principal applicant from contracting with identified group members for a pro rata indemnity for any costs ordered to be paid by the principal applicant.

The honourable member for Makin congratulated parliamentary counsel on the way in which this Bill has been drafted with such clarity. Let me raise, for the consideration of the House, a matter that exhibits something less than clarity. If one looks to the costs proceedings in this Bill, to which the honourable member for Higgins has pointed, there are at least two interpretations of the way in which costs may be applied. The first interpretation, which has been outlined by the honourable member for Higgins, is that, because there is no direct reference to costs in this Bill, the only person as a losing applicant, if I can put it that way, who may be able to have costs awarded against him or her is that representative party, himself or herself.

PARA.TAB: As the honourable member for Higgins pointed out, if that party is impecunious, it could lead to a situation where, if `greenmail', for example, had been used by an environmental group against some manufacturer to make a claim which was totally spurious, and proven by a court of law to be totally spurious, then when that manufacturer, for example, sought to recover costs from the applicant, the manufacturer was faced with the situation of only being able to recover costs against the representative party. If that party is impecunious, obviously costs cannot be recovered.

On the other hand, one can read this Bill as saying that because there is no direct reference to costs in the Bill, and because the court is able to order costs against the losing party, in fact a court could order costs against the losing party—namely, all the members of that group that is represented by the representative party.

This is an appalling lack of clarity in a Bill before the Federal Parliament. If that interpretation is correct, we have a situation where members of a party—who may be members of the party before the court unbeknown to them, because we have a situation where parties are deemed to be parties unless they opt out—not knowing that they are involved in an action, could find themselves the subjects of an order for costs against them.

There is nothing in this Bill which clearly spells out what the situation should be in relation to legal costs, other than saying that the court may make any other orders which it deems to be appropriate. I would have thought, in respect of the comments made by the honourable member for Makin, that if this were a Bill in which clarity had been expressed by parliamentary counsel, we would see a situation where the costs could be awarded either in favour of the respondent, the party who has been sued, or against the applicants, namely, all those members who may not even know that they are members of a group to a legal action.

This is the very sort of point we will find litigated before the High Court in this country one day because this Parliament has failed to spell out clearly what the situation is. Whether the interpretation which has been posited by the honourable member for Higgins or the alternative interpretation which I have posited is correct is really beyond the point of this debate. The real point of this debate is that if parliamentary counsel had been up to their duty, and if the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) had been up to his responsibility in this matter, then the question of costs in relation to these sorts of actions would have clearly been posited so that there will not be a situation where we may find we may have an appeal to a supreme court, to the full court of a supreme court and, ultimately, to the High Court of Australia.

This Government says that it wants to bring down legal costs; this legislation ought to be thrown up time and time again as an example of legislation which will do just the opposite. That question of costs ought to be addressed. I know this legislation has passed through the Senate, and the Government has the numbers in this House so it may force it through here. The other difficulties with this legislation have already been raised by the honourable member for Higgins. These are difficulties which have been clearly indicated by a variety of legal firms. SPEECH.PARA: As I indicated in the debate on the second reading, the Opposition is moving a number of substantive amendments to improve the proposal which has been put forward by the Government; some might say to radically alter it.

PARA.TAB: The purpose of these amendments is to take out the offensive aspects of the Government's proposal for class actions and to effectively introduce a system for representative proceedings which would be modelled on the best practice in the State supreme courts.

The proposed new section 33C allows seven or more persons having claims against the same person, where those claims are in respect of or arise out of the same or substantially the same circumstances and where those claims give rise to a common issue of law or fact, to have a proceeding commenced by one or more representing all of them.
Representative proceedings as would be allowed by my proposed amendment could be in respect of a broad range of matters to be litigated, such as equitable relief damages and the like.

The changes which are proposed in this amendment to section 33E would provide that those persons who wished to be represented in the representative proceeding would, before the commencement of the proceeding, consent in writing to being represented and their names would be entered in the process by which the proceeding was commenced.

This would allow persons who wanted to bring their action as a representative proceeding to effectively opt in. So that persons who had a claim and wished to have it litigated, merely by giving a written consent, could have their claim litigated as part of the one action, could have their claim litigated with the economies of scale that that would involve and could have their claim litigated in such a way that it would avoid multiplicity of proceedings. But their individual rights would not be compromised.

They would choose to exercise their rights. Their rights would be exercisable upon their written consent rather than as is proposed in the Government's Bill for their rights to be exercised for them if they failed to notify the court that they wished to opt out.

This amendment would effectively provide a system which is consonant with the exercise of traditional legal rights as we know them which would not encourage the worst features of the American class action system; nor would it be a boon to entrepreneurial lawyers with all of the flaws which the Government legislation has as I outlined in my speech during the second reading debate.

The other amendments which should be taken as a whole with these are really consequential on that fundamental change; the fundamental change from the opt-out system proposed by the Government's Bill to the opt-in system proposed by the Opposition.

So, for example, the amended section 33H would make provision for the group members who have opted in to be named in the proceeding, the nature of the claim specified, the relief specified and the common questions of law or fact common specified as well.

I should point out that the Opposition moved amendments substantially to this effect in the Senate. There are some slight differences to the amendments we have moved in the Committee. That is because we have had additional time to work on the amendments proposed and to clarify and refine them.

In the Senate, for example, we had proposed amendments which would have only allowed representative proceedings to be commenced if the claim had been the same; whereas these amendments would allow representative proceedings to cover those persons who had the same or substantially the same circumstances, and where there was not necessarily the same issue of law or fact, but a common issue of law or fact so that it would be wider to that extent. It also reflects what is substantially the position in the Supreme Court of Victoria, which is the leading model in relation to representative proceedings as they now stand.

Section 33J would be amended by our proposed amendment to provide the right of group members to withdraw their consent. It specifies the circumstances in which that could occur. Section 33L would allow the action not to proceed as a representative proceeding if it appeared that there were fewer than seven group members. As a result of these changes, there would be no need for a section 33M or section 33N as is proposed in the Bill. Section 33M provides for the Government's class actions to be effectively terminated where the cost of distributing money is excessive. Section 33N provides that the proceeding would not continue as a representative proceeding where the costs were excessive. That is quite a feasible position where class litigation is being operated on an opt-out system. When representative proceedings are being operated on an opt-in system, those particular provisions would not be necessary.

I must concede that those provisions are welcome as part of the Government's scheme. At least they allow a bit of brake on frivolous and vexatious claims. But in relation to our scheme, the substantive scheme itself would operate as a brake on frivolous or vexatious claims. So those particular sections would not, in fact, be necessary. Consequential amendments are proposed to section 33P as a result of the amendments to sections 33M and 33N. They allow a proceeding to be continued by a representative party in the event of the representative proceeding being terminated under section 33L.

We have also made provision in this alternative code which we put forward for settlement of representative proceedings and individual claims on notice. It is very important that the code be read and understood as a code. Effectively, it is put forward as a code in opposition to the Government's code, which has now been passed at the second reading stage.

I invite the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services (Mr Staples) to respond in detail to each of the points that we have made in relation to the amendment. I indicate that the Government tonight is represented by the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services. No doubt, he is an expert on class actions. He is representing the Government tonight while the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) is overseas. It is indicative of the way in which the legislation is being rushed through that it cannot even wait until the Attorney-General is back in the country.

As the Minister said before, it took the Law Reform Commission 11 years to report. It took the Government about three years to reject the report of the Law Reform Commission. But the Government's Bill was introduced as recently as September 1991. It is absolute nonsense to say that, because class actions have been discussed or were on the agenda of the Law Reform Commission 11 years ago, everybody knows what is in this Bill. It was not until September of this year that anybody knew what the shape of the Government's legislation was going to be. It was not the legislation as recommended by the Law Reform Commission. If we had all been discussing the legislation of the Law Reform Commission, we would not have been able to make specific comments on this Bill, which is entirely different.

The complexity that is involved is probably indicated by the length of time that it took the Law Reform Commission to come to any recommendation and then the length of time that it took the Government to reject it, that is, 11 years and three years respectively. Then the Government says that, once it released its Bill in September, there will have been enough discussion of its proposals in two months. It took 11 years for the Law Reform Commission to discuss it and three years to reject its proposal. Then the Government tries to pretend that in two months an entirely different and new proposal can be given adequate public airing for everybody to be acquainted with what is in it. If it has been given adequate airing and if the Government is acquainted with it, I look forward to the specific response it will make to each and every one of the specific amendments that we now move in committee. No doubt, the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services, representing the Attorney-General, will be able to respond in detail, this matter having been discussed at such length.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian economy really is still as flat as the proverbial tack. Unemployment is at 10 per cent plus and, I am afraid, will rise as a result of further recession, high real interest rates and the impact of industrial structural change in key industries. Investment in plant and equipment is in decline at minus 10.6 per cent for 1990-91.

PARA.TAB: The measures in the statement on the economy by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) are to be applauded but, to my mind, in all probability, are not sufficient to accelerate and sustain what is at best a sluggish, slow and patchy recovery from deep recession. I am reminded of the old joke about Richard Nixon's alleged toughness. Nixon is watching a man drowning 20 feet from the shore. Throwing the distressed swimmer a 10-foot rope, Nixon says, `There, I have now met you halfway'. The recent one per cent reduction in official rates and the initiatives announced by the Prime Minister in his statement are welcome. They are overdue, though and, in my mind, they are only halfway measures. The $115m extra funding for TAFE in 1992 will produce places for 40,000 more young people in the technical education system, and the advance of $15m to higher education capital funding is well justified. So is the $124m extension to the Government's labour market programs, including Newstart, Jobstart and Skillshare. This extra funding of places within the labour market program system means that 300,000 unemployed Australians will receive job training in 1992, at a cost of $774m in 1992-93.

I commend the Government for all this, and the Prime Minister is correct when he says that we must strengthen the skills of job seekers and the long term unemployed. It makes economic sense to do so, by ensuring that skills shortages do not emerge during recovery. But, as a government, we do have the responsibility, and indeed the moral duty, to ensure that this recovery occurs within a reasonable time frame. No economic growth means no employment growth, and there is no point in having the world's best trained dole queues.

In this context, the acceleration of expenditure on infrastructure with high economic returns to the nation has been dealt with in this statement. With the exception of the announcements regarding the construction of the Kingsford-Smith third runway and for the proposed development of stage one of Badgerys Creek airport, the remaining capital works projects, as announced, are of small economic and employment consequence. I am speaking of the advancement of $100m-odd of road and rail spending, which is welcomed, but not of major economic significance.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you in favour of the third runway?

TALK.START.PARA: —Several industry policy initiatives are also detailed, and they are welcome steps in the right direction. At this point it must be said that the coalition's so-called goods and services tax package does not provide the remedies to Australia's economic problems.

—It is inflationary, it is regressive and its impact upon the current account deficit, investment, employment and national savings is simply unpredictable. PARA.TAB: To pay for the $13 billion income tax cuts and the $6 billion for compensation to social security recipients, and for some additional social security measures, the coalition has resorted to a wide-ranging `savings' program and a $5 billion annual privatisation sell-off.
