Why force single parents onto the dole at a time of high unemployment, at a sensitive time in the life of a child? The unemployed, through no fault of their own, are to be forced off Job Search allowance after nine months and the new unemployed must wait longer for their benefit and sustenance.

If unemployment is to remain at 8 per cent to 9 per cent for some years, why does the Opposition wish to attack the innocent victims of ongoing recession and structural reform in key sectors of industries? I think the sharpest exposure of the Opposition's proposals to transfer tax responsibilities lies in its proposals for income cuts. In 1994 a person earning $20,000 per year would receive a once-off reduction of $15.60 per week. A person earning $90,000 per year is to get a $98 per week reduction, rising to $150 per week two years later. What does it matter if a low income earner gets a 28 per cent tax cut and a high income earner gets only 15 per cent, if in fact the difference in benefit is $130 per week in favour of the wealthy? One cannot spend percentages, and one requires dollars in the hip pocket.

How can the coalition assert that Australia must now digest a huge goods and service tax? As the Governor of the Reserve Bank says, `It is ill-timed, unnecessary and inflationary'. I believe that it requires a Herculean act of faith to dogmatically assert that the inflationary increase from a 15 per cent GST will be only 4.4 per cent. Does the assumption include changes to health insurance? No. Will all the cuts in wholesale sales tax and payroll tax be passed on in lower prices and/or increased employment? One can be absolutely sure that the inflationary expectations and inflation will rise by more than 4.4 per cent. Honourable members should take a look at the 1988-89 New Zealand experience.

If even short to medium term inflation rises by even 2 per cent more than the coalition forecasts, Australia would face a 10 per cent plus inflation rate, meaning tighter monetary policy and higher interest rates—less investment, and tighter fiscal policy than even the Opposition envisages. This is a sure scenario for employment loss rather than employment creation.

This does not mean that the measures announced by the Prime Minister are, in my view, all that is required at this time, or that the recovery is definitely on track. This Labor Government must not only expose the injustice and flaws of the Hewson package, but also initiate further policy to promote economic and employment growth. Australia demands vision, hope and jobs.

Official interest rates must fall another one per cent and very soon. Real Australian bank bill rates are 4.5 per cent higher than US Euro rates. A devalued Australian dollar would stimulate investment. I think export facilitation credits should be extended to cover all value added exports. The business tax review should be expedited and should result in accelerated tax write-offs for investment in plant and equipment. The outcome of the March economic statement's arrangements is definitely inadequate and we should speed up that review.

In conclusion, we cannot agree with the Opposition's proposed GST or the States' proposed 6 per cent State income tax surcharge; but a proposition which agrees to the maintenance of State financial assistance grants in real terms for five years from an agreed base which compensates for a phase-out of State payroll taxes is achievable.

Australians do not need a bloated, flawed, meretricious, and regressive $42 billion goods and services tax and expenditure cuts package. What Australia requires is an achievable mix of business tax initiatives and industry policy to encourage investment, exports and employment. We need such a package fast; we do not need the Opposition's GST package. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am delighted to have the opportunity of following the honourable member for Cunningham (Mr West). I will draw the attention of the House to some very interesting features of the honourable member's speech. We have to remember that the honourable member for Cunningham was, until fairly recently, a Minister in the Hawke Government. He is one who has turned very savagely against the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). He, of course, voted for the honourable member for Blaxland (Mr Keating) in the June ballot—he was one of the 44, along with the former Minister for Employment and Education Services, the honourable member for Makin (Mr Duncan). They were the leftist twins who made their peace with Attila the Hun from the New South Wales Right. They were two of the more interesting bedfellows who joined the ranks of the immediate past Treasurer.

PARA.TAB: I enter this debate tonight to say a few things about the outlook for employment in Australia. In the course of it, I want to deal with some of the more absurd and emotional criticisms that have been made of the Fightback economic statement released on behalf of the coalition parties by the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) last week. There is not the slightest doubt that this document has been widely acclaimed throughout Australia, because in contrast to the policies of the Government, this statement is an honest attempt to address the fundamental problems of the Australian economy.

I draw the attention of the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services (Mr Staples), who is at the table, and those who might disagree with our approach to economic management, to some words uttered by Mr Peter Robson, the Federal Secretary of the Public Sector Union—undoubtedly a man who has voted for the Australian Labor Party all of his life, and undoubtedly a man who will vote for the Labor Party at the next Federal election. He is one of the key players in the public sector unions of Australia. He said, `I do not agree with the philosophy of the Leader of the Opposition. I am against the policies contained in the document but at least he has stated in detail his vision and his attitude to what ought to be done for the future of this country'.

I say to the House that the reason this document has been so widely acclaimed, and the reason that this document has instilled a sense of electoral terror into the hearts of every marginal seat holder, and many more in the Labor Party, as evinced by its miserable performance at Question Time—I will come to that a little later—is that the Opposition has been prepared to nail its colours to the mast.

The Opposition—sensing the mood of despair, disillusionment and discontent in the Australian community, and the feeling on the part of people, whether Labor voters or Liberal voters, that there is something fundamentally wrong with economic management in Australia at present—has filled the leadership vacuum created by the failing fortunes of a tired and disintegrating government. If one wanted any evidence of the fatigue and the degree of disintegration, one could find it at Question Time today.

I entered this Parliament in May 1974. I watched the disintegration of the Whitlam Government; I experienced some of the difficulties in the harder, more arduous days of the Fraser Government; and I have watched the fortunes of this Government. I have not seen a worse Question Time performance from any government than the one I witnessed today. It was a Question Time performance bereft of any sense of direction from the Government. It was presided over by a man whose confidence has been shot to pieces because he knows that behind him lurks a disloyal rebellious group of people who are literally keeping their silence like Trappist monks publicly, yet privately praying that the Prime Minister's attempt to knock over the Opposition's taxation policy will fall into a miserable heap. If today's performance in Question Time is any guide, that is exactly what will happen.

I have not seen a more miserable low-grade performance from a Deputy Prime Minister. When I think of the people who have occupied that post I think of Lionel Bowen, a man admired and respected on our side of politics and his own, and I think of Doug Anthony. Then I think of the miserable contribution of the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Howe) today. So flustered was he that all he could do was indulge in a cheap personal jibe at the Leader of the Opposition. In doing so, he condemned himself out of his own mouth. He brings great discredit on that position, he brings great discredit on his Party and he brings great discredit on the Prime Minister. Shoulder to shoulder, the Prime Minister and the Deputy Prime Minister stitched together the numbers to enable the Prime Minister to survive last June.

If today is repeated—as I believe in one form or another it will be for the remainder of this week—and if the Parliament sits again before Christmas, there cannot be any doubt that the dogs will be well and truly barking over the Christmas barbeques. The Labor Party backbench will get the clear unmistakable message that it cannot possibly win with this disintegrating rabble. It has a Treasurer who cannot answer the most fundamentally simple economic questions without a voluminous Treasury brief. It has a Prime Minister who cannot command the attention of the House. It has a group of people sitting behind it half of whom are conspicuously disaffected and who are hoping and praying that the Prime Minister's attack on the economic package launched by the Opposition is a miserable failure. The Minister who has just taken his place at the table, the Minister for Resources and honourable member for Maribyrnong (Mr Griffiths), in a very portentous and overperformed delivery at Question Time endeavoured to support the puny endeavour of the Prime Minister to undermine the commitment to abolish fuel excise.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who did he vote for?
—He voted for Keating.
—We all did.
—Of course, they all did. It is interesting because here we have three Labor Party members—

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Hollis)—Order! The honourable member for Bennelong should know he should not respond to interjections. I ask honourable members to be silent in the chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do not be silly, Mr Deputy Speaker. There are three members in the House for whom I have a very considerable regard—the honourable member for Hinkler (Mr Courtice), the honourable member for Maribyrnong and the honourable member for Grey (Mr O'Neil). They all voted for the honourable member for Blaxland. They are right out in the open about it.
—What about the knock on the door?
—I will tell you something, China: that is absolutely academic and irrelevant. It has absolutely nothing to do with it.
—Order! We will not have a debate across the table. The Minister and the honourable member will not debate across the table.

—He talks about political hatred. What about the political hatred that has been demonstrated by those on the other side. Here we are, in the deepest recession that this country has experienced in 60 years, and we have the most comprehensive economic package ever launched by an opposition in the history of Australian politics. It has been widely and deservedly acclaimed as an honest attempt to address the economic problems of this country.

PARA.TAB: What I found most interesting about the Newspoll in this morning's Australian was not so much the very comforting overall result for the coalition—that was very welcome—but the comment of the Australian's political correspondent, Glenn Milne, when he said that this package has been identified as a national rescue plan. That poll was indicating to the people of Australia and to the readers of the Australian that a large number of Australians were saying, `I don't know whether it is good for me or bad for me or whether it is middling for me, but I do know it is good for my country and therefore I am going to support it'. That demonstrates that we have produced a plan that tries to address the fundamental problems of this country. The Government may not like it and it may not agree with it, but it has to concede that it is an honest and thorough attempt to address the fundamental economic problems of this country.

The response that those opposite have to adopt to the economic policy launched by the Opposition last week is not to nitpick, carp or overindulge in rhetoric but to acknowledge that there are many things in it that are good. I hope that my colleague from Hinkler, who represents a non-metropolitan area of Australia, will recognise the enormous benefits bestowed on rural and provincial Queensland by the proposal to abolish fuel excise. I hope, in the context of speaking on an economic statement dealing with employment, he will recognise the enormous contribution to job creation through the abolition of payroll tax. I hope he will recognise that when we take $20 billion of the current tax burden off Australian business, we endow it with a capacity to employ Australians that it does not currently have. That is an unarguable statistic.

We all know that the only way we can get employment growth going again in this country is to get a genuine resumption of economic growth. The honourable member for Cunningham said that no economic growth means no employment growth. He is absolutely right. I cannot think in the present economic circumstance of something more likely to get a resumption of economic growth and therefore a resumption of employment growth than taking the tax yoke off Australian business.

I quite unashamedly acknowledge, as did the Leader of the Opposition, that this is a pro-business package. A pro-business package is a pro-jobs package; an anti-business package is an anti-business package. That is the rationale. Businesses employ people. The unemployment that Australia is now experiencing is very different from what it has experienced in the past. It is spreading through the community. Over the past few months there has been a middle classing of job insecurity the like of which we have not seen in this country in my political experience. It was certainly here in the dark years of the Great Depression but on no other occasion in the past has it existed in quite the form it now takes.

The reason why those numbers are still very indifferent, the reason why the housing starts, after looking promising, have petered out, the reason why the motor vehicle registrations are not doing as well as people would like, the reason why every company director who says anything about the economy is restrained about our prospects over the next 12 months, is that people are scared stiff of losing their jobs. It is not much good saying that people can borrow money to buy a house at 8 per cent or 9 per cent because if they do not have a job they cannot even afford to pay the interest at 5 per cent, let alone the present level of 12 per cent.

In a climate of escalating job insecurity, falls in interest rates do not even touch the sides. If people are puzzled as to why we are not seeing a surge in housing activity, despite the fact that we have had major falls in interest rates, we only have to look at the level of job insecurity. Into that situation, the Opposition has injected a visionary, bold, different, honest attempt to address the fundamental problems of the Australian economy.

I say to those opposite that they should by all means join us in debate and by all means try to demonstrate to us that there are superior ways of improving the Australian economy, but they should not insult us. More importantly, they should not insult the Australian people by endeavouring—as the Treasurer and Prime Minister, to their great discredit, did today—to dismiss our plan as some kind of absurd fantasy. Those opposite might argue that it is erroneous, they might argue that it is wrong, but they cannot argue that it is flippant, flimsy and irrelevant. They have to take it seriously, because the Australian people have taken it seriously. If they are to remain in the political ring over the next 12 months they have to give a serious, and not a flippant, response to that program. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to speak tonight in support of the statement which was made by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) during the last week of sitting of this Parliament. There were basically four initiatives: the initiative in the post-secondary area to ensure that our young men and women have access to training in the long term as well as in the short term; a further expansion of labour market programs to assist the unemployed obtain and upgrade skills; the acceleration of infrastructure projects in the areas of road, rail, post-secondary education and science; and the facilitation of the development of new industries and the restructuring of existing industries. These measures totalled some $313m in the 1992 calendar year.

PARA.TAB: Firstly, it was important and responsible that the Government did not throw money at the world recession which Australia is in, that it made a very sensible and guarded response to the problems faced by this country. The problems we face are very complex. One of the biggest problems is the fact that we are involved—unwittingly and unwillingly—in a trade war. We have seen a crash in commodity prices. Approximately 80 per cent of our primary products have to be sold overseas in markets that are corrupted. We have a severe drought in more than half of New South Wales and Queensland. Consequently, many issues are simply beyond our control. Nevertheless, there are issues that are under our control, and we have continued to address those issues since we have been in government.

It is important to note that at the present time we have the second lowest level of total taxation of the OECD countries. We have inflation whipped; it is down to 3 per cent. Inflation is the greatest enemy of any country that wants to get into the trade world. Because we are so reliant on trade and because we are a trading nation with such a small population, it has been important that we should hold the line and have the courage to take on inflation as the number one enemy.

If we look at market labour costs and industrial relations we can see that under Labor there has been a reduction by some 10 per cent in non-farm unit labour costs since the Hawke Government came to power. If we look at the participation rate in the work force now vis-a-vis that of the 1950s or the 1960s, in real terms we have the best record in industrial relations. That has come about not by using a stick or dividing people but as a result of working together, through the accord, with the trade union movement and through commonsense. They are the sorts of things that have to be put into place if we are to become a competitive nation. They are the things that are working.

The problem is that while these things have been accomplished we have been hit with a world recession, a recession we were going to have whether we liked it or not. Because we could not avoid it, we were caught up in it. Had we not made the structural changes we have, we would be in a much worse position today. Nevertheless, I concede that people are hurting out there. I know what it is like. I talk to the people in my own electorate and across this country. There is no doubt, as a consequence of that hurt, that people will take notice of an alternative package that has been put forward by the Opposition during this last week.

It is healthy and constructive for us to debate the pros and cons, the rights and wrongs and the direction we should take, as the previous speaker, the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), said. I think that is healthy, because it is important to draw a clear distinction between what we on this side of the House have to offer and what those on the other side have to offer.

On Saturday night, as part of the Labor Party's centenary celebration, I had the privilege of addressing a Labor Party function in Roma, right in the heart of where our Party was formed in western Queensland. I made the observation there that I will make here tonight: nothing has changed in 100 years; the views, the prejudices and the principles that apply on either side of this House have not changed. There may be better clothes and better fashions, there may be better transport and technologies, but nothing has really changed.

What the Opposition has put forward in its package is not just the GST; it is industrial relations, it is a redistribution of wealth, it is welfare. We should look collectively at the whole package, and then we should look at our side of the House. There is a clear distinction.

I do not apologise for giving compassion a high priority. I do not apologise for caring about people. In 1891 we had a deep recession. The argument then was that people should be driven through the floor. In Queensland, the State Government bought a crooked magistrate and sent out 600 troopers to enforce its industrial relations Act.

What concerns me in the parcel of voluntary agreements is that those who can least afford it will be those most affected, that is, the unemployed, the aged, the frail and the single parents. Many single parents out there bear a stigma not of their making. It is very popular to attack single parents. I have a lot of single parents in my electorate; some of them are single parents because of car accidents, because of illness from cancer and many other problems. What disgusts me is that all these people are put into the same category and used in the attack by the Opposition. It is very easy to do that. It is just as easy for me to attack people and call them yuppies, because people will not stand up and say that they belong to that category. But 95 per cent of the people who are single parents are single parents through no fault of their own.

There may be some people who make mistakes. There may be some people who make mistakes more than once. But I do not believe we should punish the children. I do not believe we should turn our backs on Australians just to give people at the top end of the market another 10 per cent on their profits in the stock exchange so they can sip another glass of champagne in the Melbourne Club.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, that is rubbish.

—That is the real difference in this debate. It is not about grabbing the money and running with a fist full of dollars. The real difference is about the philosophy behind this debate. I will get to the rest of the debate—the honourable member on the other side interjects—in a minute. I am very pleased to embrace this debate over the next 18 months, because it is a philosophical debate. That is the good thing about this debate: we have finally got a clear distinction about what we on this side of the House stand for and what the Opposition stands for. That is why I look forward to this challenge.

PARA.TAB: There is no doubt that it is going to take time for the community to understand the complexities in this package. I think it will take time for honourable members on both sides to understand the complexities of such a thorough and voluminous package on the goods and services tax. I believe it is the duty of those on both sides of this House to fully explain the package to the community so that they can clearly understand what is represented by the Opposition's propositions for changes in taxation and what we propose.

We propose the second lowest level of taxation in the OECD countries. One of the interesting parts of this debate about removing the wholesale sales tax from primary producers and the business sector is that the changes that have just been introduced are worth approximately $454m. Changes affecting the majority of input costs and some of the inadequacies that were previously on the backs of farmers were announced in the May statement and came through recently. As a consequence, there are very few wholesale sales tax impositions on the rural sector today.

When I was in the Maranoa district on the weekend speaking to farmers and graziers and to local authority representatives, it was interesting to find that they were not even aware that they would have this weight taken off their shoulders. I guess that is part of the problem in the toing-and-froing of debate and in the publication of many topical aspects of the issue in the newspapers. This week was about the first time that I saw such a big run given in the newspapers to the wholesale sales tax exemptions, which take the impost off the farmers' backs.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you talk about watermelons. You are ruining the watermelon industry.

—What will farmers get out of this? Let us talk about the farmers in Queensland. The honourable member mentioned watermelons; I would like to talk about rockmelons, zucchinis, pumpkins and also tomatoes, and about farmers who will not receive an income this year. The honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer) would know about this because he was up in my electorate recently. He had to wait an hour to be taken through the Millaquin mill by a worker because none of the managers was free to do so. He would know that the majority of farmers who will not receive an income this year would pay an extra 15 per cent tax which would be imposed by the Opposition. That is on top of the burden they have to bear because of the crash in commodity prices, the drought and the corrupted world markets.
—Talk about what Goss is doing to watermelons.

—I am pleased that the honourable member from Victoria mentioned watermelons three times. When we come to the horticulture industry let us talk about the local domestic market. The horticulture industry in Queensland is worth $700m per annum. Of that, 82 per cent represents domestic produce. That means that 82 per cent of the industry would be taxed at 15 per cent in the domestic markets. A quick calculation indicates that that represents about $80m in taxation being taken off the farmers—money that would not go into their pockets, but would go into a conservative government's coffers.

PARA.TAB: That is what this tax would do for farmers, for the horticultural industry; it would tax them at 15 per cent. Sure I heard the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Tim Fischer) on Friday on the Henshaw program skite about how this tax will be good for tomato growers in Bundaberg because they will be able to export without input costs. The problem is that the majority of tomato growers in Bundaberg supply a domestic market. They would be taxed at 15 per cent. On top of that, in the export market inflation would double at least, based on the conservatives' figures. Let us look at what would happen, given the experience in New Zealand and other countries. Inflation would triple at least. What will happen as inflation goes up?

I will leave the honourable member for Mayo to work out his own calculation as to what the level of inflation would be. It would double at least. The Opposition has put out a figure of 4.4 per cent as a minimum. In anyone's calculation, that is double. That would make us less competitive in the export industries. At a time when we have endured the pain and got inflation down, the Opposition cowboys want to double inflation and make us less competitive. Surely to goodness, the Opposition can understand simple logic. The Opposition would tax farmers in the domestic market. The pork industry, the poultry industry, the peanut industry and the horticulture industry are predominantly domestic.

The Opposition would lob a 15 per cent tax on the farmers' backs. I will let the blokes in the Opposition explain to the National Farmers Federation and to everyone else how they will be better off with the excise exemptions on petrol as the figures start to come through to show that at the most they will get a reduction of 2 per cent or 3 per cent. Let the Opposition try to convince people that all the good-natured people at the top end who will get those reductions will pass them on to the primary producer. If the Opposition believes that, it believes in fairies at the bottom of the garden. In fact, the only thing that has not been promised in the goods and services tax package is a leprechaun for everyone's garden. Quite honestly, I would rather rely on a leprechaun than on the Opposition's package.

If we look at what it would do for primary producers, we see that it would do nothing for them. It would blow out inflation; it would make us less competitive in the export industries; and it would tax domestic produce at 15 per cent. I say to those opposite that they should have a good think about it when they come back to my area and try to tell the producers there how they will be better off. The Opposition never convinced anyone, no-one at all.

Those opposite should look at the housewives and the men who stay at home to look after families—I did that for 12 months, and it was a good education—and who go into the supermarkets. We heard the Leader of the National Party talk about the price of toothpaste and other goods coming down. People do not buy a bucket of toothpaste every week. But, my goodness me, they do buy an armful of fruit and vegetables and they do buy an armful of meat. And those items would be taxed at 15 per cent. Let the Opposition members go to South Bundaberg, to South Brisbane, to where the real heart and soul of this country is, and tell people in those areas that it will do them a good favour by putting a 15 per cent tax on the necessities of life.

It might not matter much that it occurs in the Adelaide establishment, but let me tell those opposite that it happens to matter to working class people. The real difference in this debate over the next 12 months will be that a few working class boys on this side have a good knowledge of events that occurred in the past 100 years. I tell those opposite that they will have the fight of their lives, and they will lose it. We do not intend to let Opposition members, the Visigoths of the twentieth century, ever get to this side of the House. Let me tell them that. They are in for a fight, and they will know it. In the words of Henry Lawson, if the blood stains the wattle, it will not be because of us.

TALK.START.PARA: —Fighting words from the honourable member for Hinkler (Mr Courtice)—no doubt about that. A good man, but a man whose rhetoric needs to be related to his record. The honourable member for Hinkler is a man who is best known in this Parliament for his enthusiastic, passionate support for the honourable member for Blaxland (Mr Keating) to overthrow the existing Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), to take his place and to lead this country towards some new horizon. The interesting thing, as I pointed out only the other day to the citizens of Bundaberg in the electorate of the honourable member for Hinkler, is that the honourable member for Blaxland, who the honourable member for Hinkler so passionately believes should be the leader of this nation, is the man who in 1985 masterminded the White Paper which proposed the introduction of the broadly based goods and services tax.

PARA.TAB: Amongst the rhetoric that we heard tonight we even ended up with blood on the wattle. We heard about how the poor would be plunged into greater poverty; how single mothers would simply be destroyed; how the sky would fall in; and how the world would stop spinning. But the complete tragedy that he talked about was, of course, very much part of the scheme that was proposed by the honourable member for Blaxland in 1985, supported by the current Prime Minister most passionately in interview after interview around this country, but a Prime Minister who knew all along that it was economically right for this country and that it could not afford to go along with its taxation system that dates back to 1930—the oldest living taxation system left in the industrialised world—a Prime Minister who knew all those things needed to change but who, in the end, did not have the political courage to make the change.

The honourable member for Hinkler is one of many Government members who seriously think that they can go out and run a scare campaign about how a flat earth will be created and how the economic equivalent of a nuclear explosion will devastate Australia, and actually expect the Australian electorate to believe it. Government members actually believe—no, Mr Deputy Speaker, I do not think they believe it, but they seriously hope—that enough voters will believe that to re-elect to government a party that has thrown nearly one million people onto the dole and still claims this very day to be a party of compassion.

We always hear from the Australian Labor Party—I have heard it all of my life for as long as I can remember and, presumably, all the people older than I am have heard it all their lives—that it claims to be the party of the workers and the party of compassion. Yet, whenever the Labor Party has been in office, there has been an economic crisis in this country. The people who have borne the brunt of that crisis are not the rich, they are not the members of the Adelaide establishment drinking cocktails in the Adelaide Club that Government members love to deride, they are not the people who live in Toorak or Rose Bay or wherever; they are the working people of this country. It is the low income people of this country, the people on the supporting parents benefit, who always bear the brunt of the hypocritical policies of Labor governments.

We can go right back through history. The Watson Government lasted for how long? Six months. And it was thrown out by the Parliament for incompetence. The Fisher Government was quickly thrown out as being economically incompetent. The Scullin Government, which masterminded massive unemployment in this country, was consigned to the dustbin of political history. By the way, it was the government that introduced Australia's current consumption tax—the wholesale sales tax.

Then we had the Whitlam Government—there was a war at the time of the Curtin and Chifley governments, so we can excuse them for difficult circumstances—which plunged this country into economic chaos, to the extent that even members of the current Ministry admit that the Whitlam Government was little short of a disaster. I do not think any Australians who are old enough to remember the Whitlam Government would deny that it was nothing short of an economic disaster.

Along comes the Hawke Government, and nearly one million people are simply thrown onto the dole. That is the record of the party that claims to be the party of the workers and the party of compassion. So I think it is only right for the 17 million people of this country to change their attitudes to politics once and for all, to set aside the rhetoric that they have heard from the Labor Party for 100 years and recognise that this is a political party of economic illiterates and economic incompetents that has done immeasurable damage to this country.

This Government, in its speeches on the statement that we are debating today and its denigratory contributions in Question Time, has the audacity to come into this Parliament and defend its record. This Government seriously thinks the most comprehensive economic program ever put forward by a political party in this country, the Hewson Fightback program from the Liberal and National parties, should be dismissed out of hand with a handful of trite cliches about the poor being made worse off and the rich better off, suggesting instead that Australians would be better going on in the way they are today. Nobody in this country will believe that is a sensible proposition.

The major social problem of this country today, unemployment, combined with falling living standards for those who are lucky enough to have stayed in work through the time of the Hawke Government, flows from the simple proposition that in the last eight years this country has become internationally uncompetitive. We have massive month by month balance of payments deficits and the largest foreign debt that we have ever had—a foreign debt which is one of the largest in the world and certainly the largest of the industrialised developed countries. We have a Government that has decided that the way to cope with this foreign debt and balance of payments problem is not in the obvious way, to make the country more competitive—and there is absolutely nothing in the Prime Minister's statement about making this country more competitive—but to put up interest rates to the highest level they have ever been and to plunge this country into a recession.

The recession did not happen just because there was a recession in London, Frankfurt, Tokyo or New York; the recession was deliberately engineered by the Labor Party as the solution to the balance of payments crisis and our foreign debt crisis. That was the reason the Government engineered the recession in this country—and it admits it. Nobody in the Labor Party would seriously deny that that was the reason for the recession. Let us be fair to Government members: they probably do not think it is fun to plunge nearly 1 million people onto the dole in the way a child might think it is fun to tear the wings off a fly, although one could be excused for thinking that. They did it because they thought it would solve the foreign debt, unemployment and balance of payments problems.

But Government members are not talking about the foreign debt and the balance of payments. Honourable members might recall that two years ago Government members were saying that we have to have interest rates high to deal with the balance of payments and foreign debt problems. When people said to them, `But our inflation is rather high', they used to say, `We are not like the tories over there. We do not have a fight inflation first strategy as the Fraser Government did. That is not our strategy. We are not concerned about inflation; we are concerned about the balance of payments and the foreign debt'. What happened? The Government plunged this country into the worst recession for 60 years. One of the consequences of that, just as it was a consequence in the 1930s and in 1961 when this country was in recession, was that the rate of inflation plunged as well. That obviously happens in a great recession or a depression. Prices fell very dramatically in the 1930s, they fell in the early 1960s, and the rate of inflation has obviously fallen in the last few months in Australia.

What is the Government's latest argument? It does not talk about the balance of payments or the foreign debt problem. The latest argument is, `Well, we have actually been pursuing a strategy to mop up inflation'. So the latest argument is about inflation. Guess what the Government has done. By accident, it has reduced the rate of inflation when what it was trying to do—and it is fair; any serious political party in this country ought to be trying to do it—was resolve our foreign debt and balance of payments problems. But the Government has done nothing to achieve that, because the only solution to that problem is to make this country substantially more competitive than it currently is.

As those opposite—as Disraeli would have said, that range of exhausted volcanoes over there—would have to admit, we on this side of the House are not just about being negative and attacking the Labor Party; we are about putting together a complete overhaul of the way in which this country's economy works. Our Fightback package is precisely that. It is the first time in my life that a political party in this country has had the courage to put to the Australian people a program which is not just a populist gimmick and not just trinkets and toys that might prove to be popular and glittering at election time, but a program which is honest, sincere and rational; one which is designed to overcome the problems of this country. The Government may disagree with it but, as the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) pointed out, it cannot contest the proposition that this is an honest endeavour to say to the Australian people, `For heaven's sake, don't go on with what we have been doing up until now; let's change direction'.

I have been the coordinator of the tax reform group over the last six months and I know only too well that it is a hard task going around this country convincing people that we should get rid of some of the current taxes and introduce a goods and services tax. If we were about populist politics, if we just wanted to dangle trinkets in front of people and give them handouts to get elected, we would not bother going through that difficult task—and difficult it has been.

It has been difficult because it is new and because the wholesale sales tax, the current consumption tax, is invisible, so people do not know about it. That is why it is hard to compare the GST with a wholesale sales tax. But we have done it, not because we are populist and not because we are the next generation of cynical politicians, saying we want to be in this building and we want white cars and the life of luxury, but because we have the courage to say to the Australian people, `We must change direction or we will just continue to sink'.

The package is basically about that. It gives this country and its 11 million voters a chance to choose. At the next election they will be able to choose whether they want a program that will wipe something like $20 billion worth of tax costs off the production of goods and services in this country to make it more competitive or to continue with the Prime Minister, the honourable member for Blaxland, the Treasurer (Mr Kerin) and all these tired people coming forward with their cliches about caring and compassion but with no policies designed to address the fundamental, competitive problems that this country has. That will be the choice they have.

At the end of the day, we will make a break with tradition. We will leave it to the Australian people to decide whether they want a fresh opportunity, a fresh start, a reasonable chance to build for themselves, for their children and their grandchildren or to stick with the stale old team.

One of the things that the Prime Minister has said over the years, which I think is right, is worth reflecting on: never underestimate the intelligence of the Australian people. Government members do not seriously think that the people are going to believe that a 15 per cent goods and services tax coupled with the abolition of seven taxes—including Labor's tax on jobs that the Government has decided to embrace—is going to lead to a 15 per cent increase in the price of everything they buy and that that is going to lead them on the road to rack and ruin. They will not believe it, so do not try to tell them.

Even the Treasury's own figures that the honourable member for Blaxland quoted in April of this year in the Press Club did not show that. No-one will believe Government members, so they may as well give up on that argument and get a little bit more sophisticated. Their only hope of re-election is to develop a completely new program, non-cynical, unencumbered by populist trinkets, and to try to convince people that they will make this country more competitive. They cannot do it, because they are married to the trade unions. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —The previous speaker, the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer), the Sir Laurence Olivier of the Parliament, the former head prefect, liked to go back to former Prime Ministers and former governments, and it is quite ironical that he got as far as Whitlam and then failed to go on to Malcolm Fraser, whose staff he was on when we had that `marvellous' trifecta of double-digit inflation, double-digit interest rates and double-digit unemployment. What an incredible indictment it is of the honourable member for him to come in here and cast aspersions on other Prime Ministers and other political parties in government without at least having the courage to say, `Well, look, I was on the staff of a former Prime Minister; we made some terrible blues'.
—He didn't listen to my advice.

—He can laugh; but we all go through periods when, through no fault of our own—such as at the present time when we are in world recession, when the prices for our commodities have fallen through the floor and when the rest of the world is not giving us the prices for our commodities that once we would have expected—we are caused enormous problems.

PARA.TAB: I have a great deal of respect for one of the earlier speakers, the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), who quite tragically was dumped by the Opposition. Undoubtedly, by the proverbial million miles, he is the person with the most ability on the other side. I have a deep respect for him because I think he is a person who generally speaks from the heart, and some of the things that he said I must say I am quite comfortable with.

Undoubtedly, the greatest problem that we on this side of the House have is unemployment. There is no doubt that to have nearly a million people unemployed is quite tragic indeed. I believe that all of us really want to do something about easing the horrific problems of the unemployed and the ramifications which flow on to their families. Earlier this year I was fortunate enough to be able to form a committee called the employment marketing committee and was given the responsibility of trying to get a strategy for creating long term employment. The members of that committee worked extremely diligently together. We received submissions from the ACTU, the Chamber of Commerce, the Chamber of Mines, the Chamber of Manufactures and many other interest groups that quite genuinely put forward philosophies that we could do something about creating more employment, particularly long term employment, in this country. Some of the job creation schemes, like the RED scheme, the CEP and others, have been very successful in the short term, but our strategy has to be long term employment.

Our committee presented our report only a couple of weeks ago, and the ministerial statement of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) is based to a large degree on that report. I acknowledge that the Prime Minister and Cabinet Ministers were good enough to act on that report. However, the Prime Minister's statement is only a first step along the way to implementing that report. It is working in the right direction and I believe that if the whole of it is acted upon we can go a long, long way towards having some policy in place to ease unemployment.

My own view is that the key to providing a sustainable improvement in the employment sphere is to encourage investment in industry. Government policy and spending should be targeted to ensuring that new enterprises arise and to establishing enterprises that remain viable. In my opinion, in order to provide a sustainable increase in the level of employment, government should provide policy settings to give industry the incentive to invest. Every encouragement should continue to be given to entice industries to invest in areas involved in the production of internationally tradeable goods and services. Emphasis should be put on import replacements and export expansion. The approval process for all levels of industry and business should be simplified through agreements among the Federal, State and local governments. An acceleration of the development process will remove a major disincentive to investment. I recommend that a mechanism be established to simplify and coordinate the processes confronting groups seeking development approval. It should not become another level of bureaucracy.

The Government is continuing to give priority to further easing in interest rates when circumstances permit and, in particular, is aiming for the lowest interest and exchange rates which are compatible with an acceptable inflation outcome. The key task for policy must be in generating sustained employment growth, particularly as it was the blow-out in the current account deficit and the resultant increase in the level of foreign indebtedness that were the root cause of Australia's current economic problems.

Any policy mix that fails to address the constraint on economic activity will not succeed in delivering sustainable employment growth or lower levels of unemployment. That sustained employment growth is necessary to make sustainable inroads in reducing unemployment is highlighted, inter alia, from the experiences of the 1982-83 recession, notwithstanding high employment growth during the recovery phase from that recession and subsequently only limited progress being achieved in reducing the number of jobless. This was because an overwhelming proportion of more than 1.5 million new jobs created over the period of 1983 to 1990 was taken up by new entrants to the labour force as a result of population growth and the increasing participation of the working aged population in the labour force.

The future course of labour force participation will again be important in determining the extent to which employment growth translates into reductions in unemployment in the recovery from the recession. The perennial constraints of the current account deficit on levels of high activity in the Australian economy mean that, in order to achieve sustained employment growth, there must be a sustained shift in resources towards the internationally tradeable goods and services industry. It is that output from the traded goods sector that provides the wherewithal to fund increasing levels of demand in the economy generally from which growth in employment will flow.

It is important, however, that that policy not be overly fixed on promoting investment and productivity in the internationally tradeable goods and services sector to the exclusion of other sectors of the economy. An efficient construction industry, efficient service industries, such as electricity, transport, telecommunications and finance, and an efficient community service and public administration are all necessary to ensure that resources are not drawn from the traded goods sector. In short, the focus of policy should be to promote productive investment in the economy wherever it occurs.

Implicit from the experience of the 1982-83 recession and, in particular, the difficulties in reducing the numbers of jobless in the short term is the fact that policy also must focus on relieving the plight of the long term unemployed. In the broad, the current stance and direction of the Government's policy settings are consistent with the central task of generating sustained employment growth.

In particular, and as was highlighted in the 12 March industry statement, for example, current policy recognises that the broader macro-economic settings of policy must be complemented by micro-economic and other policies more specifically targeted at improving productivity in the economy if Australian industry is to become more internationally competitive. The considerable array of labour market programs now in place, aimed at enhancing the educational, managerial and workplace skills of the labour force, including programs specifically targeted to the long term unemployed, are also integral to that process.

TAB.TAB: Fundamental to the task of generating sustained employment growth is that future wage increases be linked as closely as possible to increases in productivity, a point also being emphasised in the current policy focus in promoting greater enterprise based wage bargaining. While, in the broad, the appropriateness of the Government's current policy settings is endorsed, it is considered that within those policy settings greater focus must be placed on improving employment conditions.

PARA.TAB: One of the big things that the Government must do, and something I see it working fundamentally to do, is to reduce interest rates. We must also bring forward expenditure on public works and infrastructure. We must more effectively coordinate and streamline environmental and approval processes for major projects and show greater decisiveness in considering such projects. We must reduce our immigration and give a greater economic focus to policy in this area.

We must encourage greater equity investment in Australian enterprises by the use of superannuation funds. We must implement a more coherent regional development strategy. We must also implement more effective anti-dumping procedures. We must also provide more generous tax treatment for depreciation and research and development expenditure. We must introduce broader tax incentives for savings and increase assistance for exports.

Without an industry policy, it is unlikely that we as a nation will develop industries that are needed to employ our people in circumstances that can maintain our living standards, let alone provide for improvement in this area. To develop such a policy we need to ask what sort of industries we need in Australia. The answer seems obvious. We need to do better the things we do well. We are the world's best miners, and we are good at agriculture. We need to value add to the product we export as primary producers as much as it is practicable to do so. We also need to develop those secondary industries that our great primary industries rely upon. As the world's best miners, we should be exporting mining equipment.

I was sad that the Government did not proceed with mining at Coronation Hill. I am on the public record as saying that. It is indeed a pity that we did not do that. The development of our natural resources and the downstream processing of those resources must proceed in harmony with the maintenance of acceptable environmental standards. There is a need to establish clear and unambiguous environmental and other guidelines which must be adhered to by all parties and under which investors can proceed with confidence to develop projects in these and other areas.

We have to have a clear policy that investors, particularly in the mining industry, will be well aware of when they put money into a proposal. Obviously, where geologists have taken samples and have found rich minerals, as at Coronation Hill, we have to have the courage of our convictions and think of the export dollar and what it can do for Australia. I know the Minister at the table, the Minister for Resources (Mr Griffiths), wholeheartedly supports me on this, and I support the Minister. His philosophy is quite right. We have to give clear guidelines to investors in this country so that when they put money in they have a clear goal and they know they are likely to reap the benefits of the proposal they are investing in.

If we have positive policies—constructive policies—I think we will go a long way towards resolving this terrible unemployment problem. The Prime Minister's statement goes a long way along the right track towards developing that policy, towards creating long term employment, and it is certainly my hope that before the next election is called we will have gone a long way towards reducing the horrific level of unemployment that we have in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Recently I was given a tour around the Seymour abattoir, which is located in my electorate of McEwen. After a number of delays caused by excessive red tape and regulations, the abattoir reopened on Monday, 4 November, after being closed for more than a year after a long history of industrial problems. This abattoir, like numerous others in Victoria, found that the long and very costly industrial disputes instigated by the Australasian Meat Industry Employees Union were sending it bankrupt.

PARA.TAB: In fact, the Victorian branch of the AMIEU, and its State Secretary, Wally Curran, have been rightly blamed by farmers and abattoir operators for the closure of 13 country abattoirs in Victoria. These closures have seen the loss of hundreds of jobs and at least $180m in export earnings. Today only one-third of Victorian country towns have their own abattoir, and this shortage of killing works will mean that approximately 100,000 head of Victorian cattle will be shipped interstate this year for slaughter.

The Victorian meat industry has the highest level of strikes, labour turnover and absenteeism in Australia. The only way the Seymour abattoir could be reopened as a commercially viable enterprise was for contract labour to be used. Brian Groves of Troubleshooters Available was called in to supply contract labour and the Seymour Meat Processors Cooperative was formed. This cooperative now has 158 shareholders and wide ranging community support. Despite predictions that it would take some time before the abattoir would be profitable, it turned its first profit last Friday after only three weeks in operation. It is expected the abattoir will record a profit every day from now on.

The Seymour abattoir is licensed to kill both cattle and sheep. To date the most successful aspect of the venture has been the mutton floor, although the beef section is expected to grow substantially in coming months. Already the mutton floor is running at full capacity and processing between 750 and 800 head of sheep a day. In fact, demand for the abattoir's services in this area is such that it is looking at putting on more workers or extending working hours to cope with the extra orders.

Operating under contract labour gives the abattoir the flexibility and ability to make those changes to the work force. It also creates efficiencies and increases productivity and profits and results in higher hourly rates, as well as productivity bonuses for the workers. Initially it is anticipated that the 60 contracted workers will work on a rotation basis so that 40 workers are working at the abattoir at a given time, and that they will work for three or four days a week. Under contract labour these hours can be increased if demand at the abattoir increases.

This is in stark contrast to the past, when the employer was often faced with having to negotiate extended working hours to fulfil a large contract, sometimes six months in advance. Unfortunately, the option of extended working hours at the Seymour abattoir is being limited at the moment by the restrictive work practices of the only two workers who are trade union members, the meat inspectors, who are not receptive to the idea of working overtime. It is envisaged that this problem will be overcome in time.

There is no doubt that the Seymour abattoir will be successful. It is in an ideal location as it is in close proximity to major highways and rail links of vital importance, and it is within easy access of Tullamarine Airport. In addition, there are no similar operations within a 100-kilometre radius, which will help ensure that demand remains high. I wish everyone involved with the abattoir the very best of luck for the future.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Road Safety: Keep Left Unless Overtaking Rule

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edwards Mr R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to call upon the Western Australian Government, through the Western Australian Police Department, to introduce, as part of its Christmas road safety campaign, the mandatory application of the keep left unless overtaking rule. This, I believe, would be a major factor in improving road safety in Western Australia.

PARA.TAB: Along the way, I want to congratulate the Police Department for its efforts in improving road safety, but I would like to point out that in other States of Australia, the keep left unless overtaking rule is adhered to, and traffic management and traffic safety is certainly the better for it. I want to refer to a couple of regulations. The first refers to traffic law in New South Wales, and states:

SPEECH.PARA: Keep to the left
65. Subject to these Regulations, the driver of a motor vehicle upon a public street shall keep the vehicle as close as practicable to the left boundary of the carriageway, except—

PARA.TAB: (a) where there are two or more lanes marked on the carriageway available exclusively for traffic travelling in the direction in which the driver is travelling; or
(b) where the vehicle is being driven upon a shared traffic zone.

SPEECH.PARA: In other words, the law allows overtaking. It is made clear later in the Motor Traffic Regulations 1935, where, in section 65A (1), it is stated:

PARA.TAB: The driver of a motor vehicle upon a portion of a multi-laned road. . .

SPEECH.PARA: shall not drive the vehicle in the lane which is—

PARA.TAB: (c) furthest from the boundary of the carriageway on the left-hand side of the driver; and
(d) lawfully available for traffic travelling in the direction in which the driver is travelling,

SPEECH.PARA: In other words, keeping left on multi-laned roads unless overtaking is a mandatory requirement under traffic regulations in New South Wales. Also listed under `Traffic Offences' is a requirement which states:
Overtaking

13.3 It is the duty of a driver when following another vehicle and who seeks to overtake that vehicle to pass to the right of that vehicle at a safe distance. The overtaking vehicle keeps the overtaken vehicle on its left.
It then goes on and spells out the following:
A driver travelling in one of those lanes may pass to the left of a vehicle travelling in another of those lanes, if conditions permit him to do so with safety.
In other words, that applies if it is a multi-lane road. Quite clearly in the regulations of other States there is provision for traffic to keep to the left unless overtaking.

PARA.TAB: Sadly, this is not uniformly the case in Western Australia. The Police Department has moved to some extent to adopt this rule, but it is so confusing to the motorists that they do not realise when that rule applies. We have the situation where a person can be travelling on one of our freeways in Perth and find that there is someone in the centre lane travelling at 60 kilometres an hour. I had that experience very recently when an ambulance was trying to get through. There was an elderly driver driving at 60 kilometres an hour in the centre traffic lane. The ambulance driver could not attract his attention and almost caused an accident trying to move to the left of him. That was simply a question where the rule was not being enforced and not being adhered to. As with all of these public education matters, it is one in, all in, or one out, all out. Sadly, it was not the case of the regulations having a uniform application.

The people who are dealing with these emergency situations—the police themselves, the ambulance services and the fire services—will all say that the keep left unless overtaking rule means that they can get down the centre lane much more quickly. Certainly, even if there is only one lane, but people are keeping to the left, that emergency service vehicle can overtake more readily. Clearly the keep left unless overtaking rule is something that is applied in other States, and sensibly, and it ought to be applied uniformly in Western Australia on all carriageways because the current arrangement is confusing and people do not quite know, when they are on the appropriate carriageway, whether this rule applies. In effect, it does not work because people do not know what the rule should be.

I say to the Police Department and the State Minister: here is an opportunity to have a major initiative in terms of a road safety campaign for Christmas. They will say, `We have achieved a lot in road safety'. The answer is, `Yes, you have, because of seat belt legislation and random breath test legislation'. That is where the big gains have been made, but this would provide a further gain.

I am very concerned—and electors have pointed out to me—that the Multinova cameras used in Western Australia are used in certain sections of downhill road where the motorist finds it difficult to stay under the speed limit. One wonders what the motivation of the police is in those circumstances and where they have speed traps on very safe sections of double carriageway. We have to get the police to think in terms of how we can assist the motorist to better manage traffic. Certainly, the keep left unless overtaking rule would be one way of achieving that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. Tonight I rise on a very sad note—
—Order! The honourable member for McMillan might get my title right.

—I am sorry, Mr Speaker. I apologise for that. It was a slip of the tongue which will not happen again, I assure you. I rise tonight on a sad but important note. Honourable members may or may not be aware of the saga that is going on in Victoria where a strike in the power generation area in my electorate has just been called off. The state of play at this stage is quite simple: there is no agreement between the Government, the unions or the SEC. There is another mass meeting tomorrow to find out which way we are going. In effect, that means that to date a deal has not been done by the unions with the Government.

PARA.TAB: It is interesting to look at what this strike is all about. Often the rhetoric in the papers is about a power strike and how it is going to happen, but people need to understand at this stage that this is a strike about a private contractor shifting the overburden from the open cut at the Morwell power station. The significance of a private contractor shifting the overburden is this: for the first time in the history of the SEC, there is a proposal that private contractors operate a dredge and a conveyor belt that will shoot overburden one way. Quite obviously, if they choose to, at a later stage when they get down to the coal, they can shoot coal into the power station. The heart of the question we have to ask today is this: who are the power unions protecting? Are they protecting the workers on the job? I think not. Evidence would show quite clearly they are not.

The proposal that is being put to the workers by the private enterprise consortium is that a labourer would receive $34,991 for seasonal work which covers only 24 weeks. Full time labourers, with bonuses, would get the equivalent of $61,247. When we go through the other operators who would be operating the dredge, the conveyor belts, the trucks and what have you, we find that the fitter would get $64,500, the electrician would get $64,500, the dredge operator would get $65,918, the road runner would get $61,247, the stacker-operator would get $62,915, and the labourer, as I said before, with bonuses, $61,247. That is not what one would call an insubstantial wage.

Who is the union movement looking after in this organisation? It will tell you that it is the workers. Let me tell honourable members that of the 170-odd employees who are employed by the SEC at the moment in that operation, some 130 have approached the contractors to negotiate and to see whether they would like to work with that private operator. Out of 170 employees, 130 have approached the contractors to see whether they would like to operate the machines under private contractors. Why? It is because they will be paid fairly, paid extraordinarily well, for working very hard in the industry.

We have a situation today in the industry where union muscle is afraid of free enterprise competing in the hallowed open cut in my electorate because it will show up the rorts and perks that the unions have been able to perpetrate on the people of Victoria. The unions do not want to pass on to the consumers of Victoria the $20m in savings that have been projected over five years. They want the featherbedding to go on. This strike is totally preposterous. It is not on in this day and age. In these economic conditions it is high time that the people who are driving this strike come to the reality of the cold wind of hard economic times. In this day and age we need productivity and a fair day's pay for a fair day's work. The unions are to be thoroughly condemned for this scurrilous operation they are conducting. (Time expired)

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Trade with Asian and Pacific Rim Countries

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Courtice Mr B.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —From time to time newspaper columnists and editorial writers criticise politicians of all political persuasions, and I think that is healthy and I think that is important, but when editorial writers and columnists get it wrong and are continually perceived through the media to get it wrong—the same particular gentleman—I think it should be pointed out. Whoever wrote the editorial in the Sunday Mail of last Sunday—the consistent line has been there for some time—has got it wrong on trade. Likewise the economist's view by H. W. Herbert in the Sunday Mail has continually got it wrong in regard to trade.

PARA.TAB: Both these two people are protectionists and they have criticised both the Opposition and the Government for supporting the Cairns group and supporting liberalised trade. They imply by their remarks, by the editorial and by Herbert's column that we are letting down Australia by trading bilaterally with Asian and Pacific rim countries.

I would like to quote briefly from Herbert's column. He said the Government is unfortunately the leader of the Cairns group and the gurus in the Cairns group are of the view that Asia, the world's fastest expanding region, basically will be able to be exploited by exports from Australia. I have not quoted it word for word. The editorial in the Sunday Mail goes on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: The weakest aspects of the Opposition's logic are precisely those the Federal Government is in the least position to attack. For example, some of the leading members of the Access Economics team are on the record in support of the Garnaut Report, the document fuelling the arguments of the dryer GATT-based Cairns theorists whose naive policy has so devastated Australia.

He goes on to criticise the fact that imports from the Asia Pacific rim are coming into Australia. The sad part about this is that both the person who wrote this editorial and H. W. Herbert are ignorant of the fact that Australia exports $19.1 billion to the Asian Pacific rim countries this year and we import $11.6 billion. So if either of these gentlemen have the ability to do sums they would find out that we have a trade surplus in our favour of $7.5 billion.

PARA.TAB: If either of these clowns were able to implement his logic into policy we would lose a trade surplus in our favour of $7.5 billion. It is pleasing to see that both the Government and the Opposition understand the importance of liberalised trade, and at a time when we face a world recession and we need everyone in this country to put forward sensible and rational points of view, it does not help when someone who has the power to write an editorial in the Sunday Mail from Queensland and some character who calls himself an economist in the Sunday Mail, H. W. Herbert, continue to write this nonsense and attack both the Government and the Opposition for doing what is in Australia's interests—that is fighting for liberalised trade.

TAB.TAB: It is no wonder that there are people out there who cannot understand the facts when these sorts of characters in the media have not got the intelligence to find out the facts and report them as such so that people can be better informed.

PARA.TAB: I think it is interesting to reflect that Horace Greeley was probably the most vitriolic attacker of politicians for some 40 or 50 years in the United States, and finally Greeley retired and entered politics and stood for the Republican Party and was defeated. He died three months later of a broken heart because he had no guts. He had no ability. But in 40 years behind a pen he was able to attack everyone who had the courage to stand up and make a decision.

What I suggest to the clown in the Sunday Mail who writes the editorial and to H. W. Herbert is that they find out that it is in Australia's interests to have bilateral trade with Asia and it is in our interests when we have a trade surplus of $7.5 billion to continue to build upon that trade and it is that very essence that is going to help us trade out of our recession. So quite frankly both these characters should go back to preschool and learn the facts of life.

Migrants and refugees should be allowed to come to our country. There is no harm, it is good. They want a better life. Their country might be in war, or a political crisis. If they come, it is mean to hurt them and call them names just because they come from another country to seek new life. How would you like it if our country started war and you wanted to escape to another country but they didn't want you?
Wouldn't that be sad? And if you did go to another country to live would you like people hurling insults at you, just because you're different?
If no one had come to Australia from other countries, you wouldn't be Australian, would you?
Put all of these things together and it forms one idea. PEACE.
That is how I want to see Australia in the year 2000. PEACEFUL.

PARA.EMPHASIS: How I want to see Australia in the year 2000

PARA.TAB: The year 2000 is approaching rapidly, but at the present time Australia's future is uncertain. Current economic, employment and environmental situations are most likely to effect the outcome of Australia's future in the year 2000. However, aside from these areas which may effect our future, there is still going to be a future whether good or bad.

Personally though, I would like to see Australia in the future as a prosperous and economically stable country. I hope Australia will be leading in the medical field, finding cures for diseases, also providing improved and reasonably priced health care for the ill.

I also hope that in the year 2000, Australia will be addressing environmental issues and actually doing something to fix the problems of pollution, destruction of forests, land erosion and the effects of land clearance on native animals, making them endangered, a now frequent occurrence.

In the year 2000 I hope we will see Australia fully recovered from the recession and have a thriving rural industry, which will again be the `backbone' of the country. I hope we will have a stable line of trade between other countries which will be of benefit to both Australia's economy and people.
I hope to see a more democratic country in the year 2000, with more rights for the `ordinary' people, free press and the opportunity for more private enterprise.
It would be good to see a better education system in the year 2000 and the opportunity for all children to receive adequate, free education.
In the year 2000, I hope that more jobs will have been created, so as to provide the unemployed with an opportunity to earn a wage which enables them to support both themselves and their families.

I also hope that more people will be buying Australian goods and supporting local manufacturers. I hope there will be an increase in companies manufacturing goods mainly for Australia, which will aid in the decrease of our trade deficit.

Perhaps in the future, we will live in harmony with the Aboriginal people of our country. Everyone will accept them as the rightful owners of Australia and hand them the rights that go along with the title.

I have two important hopes for the future. The first one being that all homeless and less well off people are provided with adequate housing, food and employment. Secondly, I hope that in the year 2000, there will be no more violence, only peace, so no-one will live in fear of being attacked or having their homes burgled.
In the year 2000, many of my hopes for the future may not have eventuated, but we can all try to make a better future for ourselves, together.
