DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Canberra and South-East New South Wales Region

TALK.START.PARA: —In the last few days, the coalition parties have launched their Fightback program. It is evident that there will be a fight back because of the treatment that Canberra and the south-east region of New South Wales receive in this program. There will be a fight back all right—by the same mob that wound down Canberra between 1975 and 1983. In 1975 Queanbeyan was a prosperous region: it had public servants in its office space; the Snowy Mountains scheme was strongly staffed; and people from Canberra travelled to the Snowy Mountains and down to the south coast for tourist purposes.

PARA.TAB: By 1983 that had all changed: a four storey block of offices was completely empty in Queanbeyan and trade was down on the south coast and in the Snowy Mountains. In fact, employment is one per cent higher now on the south-east coast of New South Wales than it was in 1984. In Queanbeyan, employment is 3 per cent higher now than it was in 1984. That is what the fight back for Canberra and the south-east region of New South Wales is all about. It is turning back the clock to those sad old days between 1975 and 1983.

If we look at Queanbeyan now, we find that the offices are, once again, substantially full. When the Commonwealth looks at its requirements for office space in areas in Canberra it takes into account the space that is available in Queanbeyan and automatically includes it in its assessment.

The Opposition has come up with a proposal not only to reduce the number of people in the Public Service by 5,000 to 6,000, but also to transfer public servants from the Canberra region to Sydney and Melbourne. The Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) wants people to live in the real world. Canberra apparently is not the real world. If he sends the departmental heads and their entourages to Sydney and Melbourne, they will go to places such as Lane Cove and stay at places like Toorak. Is that the real world compared with Canberra? I do not think so.

In Canberra and Queanbeyan we find people of all types. There are derelicts, prosperous big business people, church leaders and people who are involved in a wide range of services, such as wholesale industries and transport industries. Whether we live in Canberra or Sydney, we select our own friends. We associate with people in the Public Service and people in business. There is a great mixture of people in Canberra and it is a natural area for decentralisation.

I think that `wind down' would be a better term than `fight back'. If we look at the proposals of members of the Liberal and National parties in Fightback!, we find that they really intend to wind down. The Opposition is going to sell the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation in Cooma. Once again, we will see office space wound down; shops closing their doors in Queanbeyan and on the south-east coast; the Snowy Mountains Hydroelectric Authority could be considered for dispersement to the States or to private enterprise; and we will see policies which have been developed to sell Telecom. We will see all of that happen. Of course, there are no policies at all on the important resource industries, particularly the timber industry. Where are the Opposition's policies on the fishing industry? It has no industry policies at all.

The south-east region, particularly the Canberra and Queanbeyan area, is a natural area for decentralisation. It is extraordinary that the Leader of the Opposition would think about transferring people to choke up the already choked-up areas of Sydney and Melbourne. We have seen great improvements in this region such as radio, television, water supply and sporting facilities. This is not just because of the local member or just because of this Government; it is because there are people out there who are prepared to share their ideas and the Government is prepared to listen to them.

People in the electorate of Eden-Monaro will fight back. The electorates of Fraser, Hume and Gilmore—all the electorates in and around Canberra—will fight back because they know what happened to them under the Fraser Government. Canberra is a major regional centre and we, in the region of Canberra and south-eastern New South Wales, want it to stay that way.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to draw attention to the treatment of the Opposition's Fightback package by the Sydney end of the Fairfax press over the last few days. I want to make it quite clear through this chamber that these things do not go unnoticed. There has been a tremendous reception to the Opposition's package over the last few days.

PARA.TAB: I refer to the Sydney Morning Herald on Friday. The whole of the front page has been devoted essentially to an attack on the Opposition's package. If it were not for the fact that the Labor Party leaked it 24 hours before and the reporters did not have a chance to distort anything in the first period, it would not have been possible to know exactly what we were about. On Friday, the front page of Sydney Morning Herald was headed in big letters `Bonanza for the Rich'. TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services, upon notice, on 9 September 1991:

PARA.TAB: (1) Has his attention been drawn to concerns expressed by the Alliance for the Mentally Ill (AMI) and others about the provision of funding and services under the Disability Services Act.

(2) Do persons with psychiatric disabilities receive a lower priority than those with other disabilities in claims for funding and services under the Disability Services Act; if so, why are they discriminated against.
(3) Does he or his Department consider persons with psychiatric disabilities to be the responsibility of State governments.

(4) Are funds and services comparable to those provided under the Disability Services Act available to persons with psychiatric disabilities under any State legislation; if so, which funds and services in which States.
(5) Will he review the provision of services to persons with psychiatric disabilities under the Disability Services Act.

(6) Has his attention also been drawn to concerns expressed by the AMI and others at conditions to be attached to disability and sickness benefits under which support may be withdrawn on grounds and in a manner which may operate unfairly against persons with psychiatric disabilities.

(7) Will he take steps to ensure that psychiatrically disabled persons in receipt of disability or sickness support will not be denied that support due to (a) inability to comply with his Department's requirements, (b) unwillingness to submit to treatments such as neuroleptic medication which may cause harmful long term side effects, (c) unreasonable limits on claims for the same condition within a two year period, (d) excessively narrow discretionary powers in examining officers or panels and (e) lack of availability of training and appropriate work.
(8) Will he review proposals to reduce the rate of disability support pension for those under 21 years of age.

(9) Will the Commonwealth discontinue tied grants to the States under Commonwealth-State disability agreements; if so, (a) what will be the effect on the availability of funds and services for the psychiatrically disabled and (b) how will the provision of Commonwealth funds for those purposes be assured.

(10) Has his attention also been drawn to the de-institutionalisation of the psychiatrically disabled being applied in every State; if so, (a) will the process increase the demand for disability services and (b) what additional Commonwealth funds will be required as a result.
(11) Will the Commonwealth monitor the provision of services to the psychiatrically disabled now provided by the Commonwealth but which will be taken over by the States; if so, how.

(12) Will the proposed new Medicare charge for medical consultations have an adverse effect on the psychiatrically disabled by creating an obstacle to their access to medical services; if so, what steps will be taken to avoid this.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) I am aware of concerns expressed by the Alliance for the Mentally Ill (AMI).

(2) Funding is allocated to services on the basis of need, and this process is being further refined by the introduction of a needs based planning system. There is no specific priority allocated to people with a disability arising from any specific area of impairment.

(3) Historically, most services for people with psychiatric illness have been the responsibility of State/Territory Governments. It is appropriate that services for people while they are psychiatrically ill should continue to be the responsibility of State health agencies. People with stabilised psychiatric conditions who may be considered to retain a psychiatric disability, are a legitimate long term responsibility of the Disability Services Act (DSA). The involvement of the Commonwealth in meeting the needs of those with psychiatric disabilities was expanded in the 1990 Budget, with the establishment of special Commonwealth Rehabilitation Service (CRS) units in all capital cities, Alice Springs and Shepparton. These will have people with psychiatric disabilities as the major target group. They will provide vocationally oriented rehabilitation programs to people applying for disability pensions who also have a psychiatric history, are not necessarily stabilised, and would not otherwise have access to vocational and rehabilitation options. Under the Commonwealth State Disability Agreement (CSDA) the funding and administrative responsibilities for different types of services are to be rationalised. Under these arrangements, the Commonwealth will administer employment services and States/Territories will be responsible for accommodation and community support services. Decisions on the allocation of specific services will be decided by the type of service and not by the nature of the impairments of individual clients.

(4) Currently, State/Territory Governments provide a range of services for people with psychiatric disabilities in accordance with their respective State and Territory legislations. However, under the CSDA, which focuses on services which provide ongoing support to people with disabilities to participate in the community, each State/Territory Government is required to enact legislation complementary to the DSA prior to the Agreement coming into effect within a State/Territory. The requirement for complementary legislation ensures the extension of the benefits of the DSA to all people with a disability regardless of whether services are funded by the Commonwealth or a State/Territory Government.

(5) As services are being provided in response to need rather than targeting specific types of impairment, and in view of the rationalising of disability services under the CSDA, I see no need to review services to persons with psychiatric disabilities.

(6) I am aware that some concerns have been raised about conditions attached to disability and sickness benefits. The following answers to questions 7 and 8 have been provided by the Minister for Social Security:

(7) (a) Officers of the Department of Social Security are aware that people with psychiatric disabilities often need extra assistance to enable them to comply with departmental requirements and a number of processes have been implemented to address this problem. For example, the Department's computer system will have the facility for noting that a particular client's disability may affect his or her ability to comply with departmental requirements. In such cases special arrangements can be made.
(b) From November 1991, the Social Security legislation will not require any pensioner, allowee or beneficiary to submit to medical treatment as a condition of payment of income support.

(c) The payment of sickness allowance will be limited, in most cases, to two years. In specific circumstances, such as a worsening of the medical condition, payment may be made for a further period. The legislation does not place specific time limits on the payment of disability support pension. (d) Eligibility for pension, benefit or allowance is determined in accordance with the Social Security Act. Examining officers and disability panels have a broad range of discretionary powers regarding the assessment of client's suitability for training, rehabilitation and employment programs.

(e) As part of the changes to income support arrangements for people with disabilities the availability of training, rehabilitation and employment programs has been increased. By 1993-94 there will be:

an additional 10,000 CRS places, most of which will be available to disability support pensioners and sickness allowees. Some 1,200 of these places will be designed specifically for clients with psychiatric disabilities.
an additional 6,500 places under the Department of Employment and Education's Jobtrain, Jobstart and Jobsearch programs will be available to people with disabilities.
an additional 4,000 employment places in Supported and Competitive Employment will be created through the Disability Services Program.
(8) I have given an undertaking to disability and welfare groups to keep the disability support pension rate for young people aged 16-20 under review.

(9) Initially, funding provided to States/Territories under the CSDA will be paid as a Specific Purpose Payment (SPP). However, the final method of funding will be decided in the context of the decisions taken at the November 1991 Special Premiers' Conference in relation to vertical fiscal imbalance, tied grants and functional reviews.

It should be noted that it has been agreed as part of the CSDA that the rationalisation of disability services provision will not be seen by either level of government as an opportunity to reduce funding and that the financial effort for disability services in 1989-90 will be maintained by each level of government. It should also be noted that under the CSDA the Commonwealth is providing significant additional funding to the States/Territories. This funding amounts to an additional $245 million over the five year life of the Agreement; of which $100 million is for growth in services, and $145 million is to improve quality of services.

(10) I am aware of the strong community demand for people with disabilities to have the support they need to live in and as part of the community. This demand is acknowledged by the Commonwealth through the DSA, which provides over $300 million to assist in subsidising the cost of such support, provided through appropriate community based organisations. The substantial additional funding made available to the States/ Territories by the Commonwealth under the CSDA will increase the resources available. Despite this significant expenditure by the Commonwealth on community support services, even greater amounts are spent by State/Territory Governments on institutional care. De-institutionalisation, if done with a concern for the clients of such services, will also allow the redirection of the resources that are locked up in large institutions, towards the provision of community based services that meet clients needs. Under the Building Better Cities initiative announced in the recent Budget the Commonwealth will support agreed area strategies to improve Australian cities, which may include institutional reform initiatives by State/Territory Governments.

(11) Under the CSDA, accommodation and other support services for people with disabilities (including those with psychiatric disabilities) which are the responsibility of State/Territory Governments, as well as employment services which are the responsibility of the Commonwealth, will be administered in accordance with the requirements of the Agreement. It is important to note that the CSDA embodies the Principles and Objectives of the Commonwealth Disability Services Act which focus on the provision of quality outcomes for people with disabilities.

It should also be noted, however, that before any transfer occurs within a State/Territory that State/ Territory is required to enact legislation complementary to the Commonwealth Disability Services Act (1986).

In addition, it should be noted that Commonwealth and States/Territories agreed at the recent Joint Meeting of Health and Social Welfare Ministers to have a National Mental Health Policy. The contents of the policy have yet to be agreed between the Commonwealth and the States/Territories.

(12) Medical services rendered by specialists to people with a disability arising from a psychiatric impairment (including attendances by consultant psychiatrists) covered in the Medicare Benefits Schedule will not be affected by the new charging arrangements to Medicare announced in the recent Budget.
However, all people (including those with psychiatric problems) who attend general practitioners will be affected by the changes unless they hold one of the following cards:
Health Benefits Card
Health Care Card
Pensioner Health Benefits Card
Pharmaceutical Benefits Card
Service Pensioner Benefits Card
Specific Treatment Entitlement Card
Personal Treatment Entitlement Card
Dependant Treatment Entitlement Card

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Trade and Overseas Development, upon notice, on 8 October 1991:

PARA.TAB: (1) Further to the information in the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade's publication (ISBN 0 642 14669 1) on the spread of non-tariff measures (NTMs) as a means by which overseas countries protect their internationally uncompetitive industries, what specific measures or practices are conventionally accepted to be commonly used as NTMs.

(2) With respect to each of the cases referred to in part (1), (a) how is the NTM applied by a Government to achieve a protectionist outcome and (b) what are the problems in defining the role of the NTM as a protectionist measure.
(3) What is the current assessment of the degree to which NTMs have proliferated.
(4) Is there any evidence that certain NTMs are being used with increasing or decreasing frequency.

(5) Have any countries been identified as using NTMs against Australian exports; if so, (a) which countries, (b) with respect to each country, which Australian exports are affected and (c) to what extent in dollar terms is each export affected.

(6) Is he able to say whether the (a) World Bank and (b) UN have reached any conclusions regarding the growth and impact of NTMs; if so, (i) what are the respective conclusions and (ii) does the Government accept the conclusions.
(7) Has the Government undertaken, or will it undertake, any initiatives to offset the impact or reduce recourse to NTMs by overseas countries; if so, what initiatives will be undertaken.
(8) Has the Government assessed in detail the role of NTMs in international trade; if so, will the results be made available for scrutiny.
(9) Is there any scope for applying NTMs against overseas trading countries to the same extent as those applied by them against Australian exports; if so, what are the details.

(10) Is there any scope for imposing on all imported products the same standards in (a) health, (b) safety, (c) additive, (d) labelling and (e) packaging requirements as the countries of origin impose on Australian exports; if so, what are the details.

(11) What technical and other difficulties (a) would follow from taking the reciprocal action referred to in parts (9) and (10) and (b) exist with respect to estimating the costs flowing from inspection, storage and freight of imposing the requirements referred to in part (10).
(12) Can an anti-dumping duty, refundable with interest if dumping is proved not to have taken place, be imposed on countries believed to be dumping goods in Australia; if not, why not.
(13) Under existing arrangements with respect to dumping, does the burden of proof fall on local authorities rather than the exporting country; if so, why.

(14) What are the advantages and disadvantages of (a) appointing an anti-dumping commissioner empowered to act when approached by industries concerned by dumping, (b) requiring that the commissioner act when industries provide prima facie evidence that dumping has occurred and (c) requiring importers to provide substantiated evidence of the landed costs when dumping has been alleged.
(15) What are the key reasons for the time which elapses between the Anti-Dumping Authority receiving allegations of dumping and counteraction being taken.
(16) Will the Government take steps to reduce the time referred to in part (15); if so, what are the details.

(17) What are the advantages and disadvantages of levying import duties, as well as other specific countermeasures, on imports with respect to which there is evidence of subsidisation by an overseas Government.
(18) To what extent are the measures referred to in part (17) consistent with the principles of free trade underpinning the current round of GATT negotiations.
(19) Could the measures referred to in part (17) be adapted so that they were consistent with the principles underpinning GATT; if so, how.
(20) What specific trade practices, policies or mechanisms could Australia adopt to protect itself from corrupt pricing strategies used by exporters to Australia.

(21) Has the Government adopted any of the measures referred to in part (19); if so, (a) which measures, (b) was each measure deemed the most appropriate for the given circumstances; if so, why, (c) how effective has each measure been, (d) how is that effectiveness evaluated and (e) will each measure's effectiveness improve over time; if so, why.
(22) Has the Government elected not to adopt any of the measures referred to in part (19); if so, (a) which measures and (b) why was each not adopted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) and (2) The following is a listing of the more significant measures which are conventionally accepted to be used as non-tariff measures (NTMs) and a description of how each is used by governments to achieve a protectionist outcome—

Prohibition—embargoes or prohibition of particular imports may be applied for various political, social, economic or sanitary reasons. This measure is usually applied through import regulations. It is often difficult to identify when such measures are used to protect domestic industry.

Quantitative Restrictions including quotas—explicit limits on quantities imported, either global limits or according to country of origin. These measures are usually applied through import regulations. In certain circumstances such measures are permissible under the GATT, such as to safeguard domestic industries from sudden surges in imports or for balance of payments reasons. However, a number of countries use such measures to provide long term protection to particular industries.

Import Licensing—the requirement for a permit prior to import can act as an NTM if procedures are unnecessarily complex or result in lengthy delays in approvals. As the primary purpose of licensing is often genuine, such as statistical collection, it can be difficult to define as a protectionist element. This measure is generally applied under import regulations.

Variable Levies—variable import levies are like an open-ended tariff and are the difference between the landed import price and an administratively determined price (threshold price) below which imports are prohibited. They are a major NTM on agriculture, in particular those imposed by the EC.

Voluntary Export Restraints (VERs)—under ``voluntary'' restraint arrangements, exporters agree to limit exports to agreed levels to avoid the imposition of mandatory import restrictions. Examples of Australian exports affected by VERs are beef and steel. Often such arrangements are imposed on exporting countries under threat of more severe restraints if other procedures are adopted.

Export Subsidies—Government payments to exporters enable normally uncompetitive goods to be sold at subsidised rates on world markets. The resultant lowering of prices has a significant effect on the exports of non-subsidising traders such as Australia and can lead to the loss or disruption of traditional markets.

Production Subsidies—subsidies can act as an NTM through import replacement by domestic production, not only of production by the firm receiving the subsidy, but also through local content requirements. In addition, subsidies can be used to produce surpluses that are required to be exported. Not all subsidies would be regarded as NTMs, e.g. those not specific to individual firms or industries may not be considered as trade distorting.

Packaging and labelling—national requirements that compel exporters to package or identify goods in a particular way can act as barriers to trade, even when designed for health or safety reasons, rather than as a protectionist measure. Exporters face greater costs than domestic producers by having to meet different national and state requirements.

Standards—like packaging and labelling, national standards can be used to impede trade even when designed for quality performance or safety reasons. Particular concerns arise when national standards differ from internationally accepted levels.
Government Purchasing—Government procurement practices can be used as an NTM if they discriminate in favour of domestic suppliers over more competitively priced or better quality imports.

In most cases countries devise NTMs in order to restrict imports or to provide a perceived commercial advantage to its industries. The problem in defining the role of NTMs as protectionist measures is that such measures often lack transparency and are difficult to evaluate. Frequently a range of NTMs are applied concurrently. In some cases measures which are considered legitimate in terms of GATT commitments are applied in such a way as to create uncertainty and to harass foreign suppliers. Some other measures can be either inconsistent with countries' obligations to the GATT or are of uncertain consistency with the GATT. These are so-called 'grey area' measures. Of these, the most frequently used today is the voluntary export restraint.

(3), (4) and (6). In a major study of NTMs, the World Bank in its 1987 World Development Report, concluded that NTMs have replaced tariffs as the main instrument of protection in many industrialised countries. Since 1974 the incidence of NTMs has increased significantly, particularly in the areas of textiles and clothing, cars, steel, electronics and footwear.

The World Bank Report indicated an increase in the application of a core group of NTMs on imports by industrialised countries from all sources between 1981 and 1986. The proportion of imports by industrialised countries from other industrialised countries affected by NTMs increased by almost 25% in this period. Statistics gathered by the United Nations over a similar period suggest that the use of NTMs by newly industrialised and developing countries had also increased in certain industry sectors.

More recent GATT reviews of world trade developments indicated that while some new measures had been introduced, most recent changes in measures used to restrict exports were reductions, liberalisation or phasing out of various NTMs. The GATT has identified significant liberalisation in the area of import licensing in a number of countries, particularly those in Latin America and often the replacement of import embargoes with quotas.

The Government accepts the general conclusion of the World Bank report that since the mid-1970s average tariff levels have declined, particularly in industrialised countries. However, for some countries the use of NTMs as a barrier to trade have become more widespread, especially in the early 1980s. There is evidence to suggest that since the commencement of the Uruguay Round in 1986 there has been a slow down in the use of these measures. Indeed a number of countries have announced substantial trade liberalisation steps including the removal of some NTMs since that time. Australia is continuing to negotiate with its trading partners for the removal of NTMs affecting our vital trade interests.

(5) It is an unfortunate fact of life that most countries apply NTMs to varying degrees and for different reasons. In the course of the Uruguay Round agricultural and market access negotiations, Australia has identified the use of NTMs on items of export interest by a number of our major trading partners. These countries, together with some of the key Australian exports affected, are as follows:
Austria—meat, fruit, grains, liquor
Brazil—wheat
Canada—meat, dairy, ice cream, liquor, processed minerals
European Community—meat, dairy products, vegetables, fruit, liquor, coal, minerals, vehicle parts, leather, steel
Finland—meat, dairy products
India—coal, wool, steel, processed minerals
Indonesia—meat, fish, dairy products, wheat, vehicle parts, steel, furniture
Japan—dairy products, grains, leather, coal
Korea, Republic of—meat, fish, dairy products, grains, fruit, sugar, pharmaceuticals, aluminium, zinc, electrical appliances
Malaysia—dairy products, sugar, pharmaceuticals, vehicle parts, domestic appliances, glass, furniture
Mexico—dairy products
Norway—meat, dairy products, aluminium
Pakistan—dairy products, fruit, wheat, confectionery, liquor, steel
Philippines—meat, fish, coal, pharmaceuticals, steel, vehicle parts, furniture
Sweden—meat, dairy products, wine
Switzerland—meat, dairy products
Thailand—fish, dairy products, wool, steel, vehicles and parts, furniture
United States—meat, dairy products, grains, steel
Yugoslavia—iron ore, coal, wool

In a few of the above cases, countries assert that the applicable NTMs are designed to protect the health, safety or consumer interests and do not discriminate between domestic or imported products. Furthermore, since the commencement of the Uruguay Round, NTMs on some of these exports have been removed or liberalised.

There is no readily available estimate of the additional cost NTMs impose on exports, unlike tariffs which are quantifiable. The Office of the United States Trade Representative, in its 1990 Foreign Trade Barriers Report, has noted the limitations of any valuation put on NTMs.

(7) The Government has been very active in the Uruguay Round in seeking to eliminate or reduce NTMs on products of importance to Australia. In agriculture Australia is seeking to eliminate non-tariff import measures by their conversion to tariffs. Australia has taken a leadership role on agriculture, including through the coalition of agricultural exporting countries (the Cairns Group) which Australia chairs.

The Government is also negotiating with its major trading partners for the elimination or reduction of NTMs on natural resource-based and manufactured products as indicated in (5) above, as part of the Uruguay Round market access negotiations. Request lists for items of export interest to Australia have been submitted on each of these countries after consultation with interested parties including the Departments of Primary Industries and Energy and Industry, Technology and Commerce, Austrade, the ACTU, industry organisations, individual exporters and State Governments. Australia has also received from a number of our trading partners requests to modify or remove perceived non-tariff measures.

In addition to the market access negotiations, the Uruguay Round is also addressing how existing GATT rules might be tightened to minimise the ability of countries to circumvent their GATT obligations through the use of non-tariff measures.

Apart from the Uruguay Round, the Government has an ongoing commitment to raising NTM issues in international fora, such as the GATT and bilaterally such as the ongoing representations made to the EC on the CAP and coal subsidies; to the United States on the Meat Import Law, sugar quotas applied until recently, EEP and voluntary export restraints on steel; to Japan on rice, coal subsidies, meat quotas and dairy and starch restrictions; and to Korea on import restrictions applied to a range of products.

(8) The Government's efforts have concentrated on negotiating the removal of NTMs identified as barriers or major distortions to Australian exports. The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade intends to publish the results of NTM liberalisation achieved at the conclusion of the Uruguay Round.

(9) No. The Government does not support the use of NTMs as a means of combating measures used by our trading partners. Such actions would undermine Australia's international efforts which recognise that NTMs are, in general, trade restrictive and to the greatest extent possible their protective effects should be eliminated.

(10) Products imported into Australia are required to meet Australian standards in relation to health, safety, additives, labelling and packaging. Australian standards are amongst the highest in the world. All Contracting Parties to the GATT have the right to determine the rigour by which such standards are applied, provided the same standards apply to imported and domestic products without discrimination.
(11) See answers to 9 and 10.

(12) The Agreement on Implementation of Article VI of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (the Anti-dumping Code) to which Australia is a signatory provides that provisional measures may be taken to prevent injury during the investigation of dumping allegations. These measures may take the form of a provisional duty or (preferably) a security—by cash deposit or bond—being not greater than the provisionally estimated margin of dumping. The Agreement makes it clear, however, that provisional measures may only be taken after a preliminary finding has been made that there is dumping and sufficient evidence of material injury, caused by dumping, to the Australian industry producing like goods. Similar rules are prescribed in relation to subsidies. Positive preliminary findings are investigated further by the Anti-Dumping Authority (ADA) which recommends to the Minister whether anti-dumping duties or countervailing duties should be imposed. In the event that the final decision does not support the preliminary finding, any cash securities are refunded without interest being paid.

(13) No. In the course of the investigation the Australian Customs Service and the ADA seek detailed information from importers, exporters and applicants to verify their claims and determine whether dumping action is appropriate. If exporters do not co-operate, Customs and the ADA can rely on the best information available, including claims made by the applicant.

(14) The Comptroller of Customs is empowered to investigate claims by local industry about alleged dumping and subsidy. The Comptroller, acting in accordance with the GATT and its Codes, must first determine that the matters set out in the application constitute reasonable grounds. As set out in the response to question (12), under the provisions of the GATT neither the Comptroller nor an anti-dumping commissioner may make a preliminary determination without further investigation. Customs has the power to ascertain the landed cost of imports.

(15) The period between an application being accepted and a preliminary finding which results in provisional measures being put in place must not exceed 135 days, or 155 days in the case of complex applications. Within the first 35 days the Comptroller must satisfy himself that the matters set out in the application would, if established, constitute reasonable grounds for anti-dumping action. If so, Customs starts an investigation leading up to a preliminary finding. That investigation is required to be completed in the next 100-120 days. During this period Customs investigates the case and verifies overseas and local information contained in the application and any submissions. The GATT Codes require that overseas parties and importers/exporters be given ample opportunity to make representations and Section 269TC of the Customs Act 1901 allows 40 days during the investigation period for interested parties to provide submissions or rebuttals of the claim. After provisional measures are put in place, the ADA has 120 days in which to reach a final finding and recommendation to the Minister on the publication of dumping duty notices. This follows from the GATT Code requirement that provisional measures are not to be in place for longer than four months.

(16) On 12 March 1991 the Government announced an overall reduction of 40 days in the maximum time which can be taken to reach a preliminary finding. The anti-dumping and countervailing system is currently the subject of a review which, among other matters, will examine options for reducing the time to process the application and investigate the claims. The review is expected to be completed by December 1991.

(17 to 19) Under the GATT, import duties or tariffs can be applied to imports at any level provided that any bindings (commitments on maximum tariff levels entered into in past rounds of trade negotiations) are observed or renegotiated. Such import duties must be applied on a non-discriminatory basis and cannot therefore apply only to subsidised imports.

Procedures for the introduction of duties to counter such practices are available under Article VI of the GATT and the Subsidies Code. Under the GATT and its Subsidies Code, specific countermeasures can only be applied to imports of subsidised products where it has been demonstrated that a subsidy exists, material injury is occurring or is threatened to a domestic industry and there is a causal link between the subsidy and the injury. Provided these conditions are met, countervailing duties are consistent with the GATT and will continue to be so after the conclusion of the Uruguay Round.

Levying import duties without observing these procedures would put Australia in breach of its GATT obligations and invite action by other GATT Contracting Parties. Furthermore, such a practice would not sit comfortably with Australia's position in the Uruguay Round negotiations on Subsidies and Countervailing Measures, which is for significant strengthening of GATT rules and disciplines in this area.

(20) The Government has adopted a multifaceted approach to minimising the exposure of Australian industry to unfair foreign trading practices in its home market and to reduce the incidence of corrupt trading practices in overseas markets.

Recently the Government strengthened and streamlined Australian procedures on anti-dumping and countervailing provisions. The maintenance of effective and responsive anti-dumping and countervailing provisions that are consistent with our international obligations remains a central tenet of the Government's industry policies.

At the multilateral level, Australia is seeking improved disciplines on agricultural subsidies, strengthened provisions on anti-dumping and subsidies and the elimination of non-tariff barriers by our trading partners. In the region the Government has accorded high priority within the Asia Pacific Economic Co-operation Forum (APEC) to detailed analysis of ways to approach non-discriminatory trade liberalisation, with the objective of this becoming a central focus of APEC's work following the Uruguay Round. Bilateral representation by Ministers and officials to other governments is undertaken to prevent or reduce damage as a result of unfair trading practices, including pricing. The Government's bilateral policies are also directed to ensuring Australia is well positioned to take advantage of rapid changes occurring in the international trading environment, including in our own region, Europe, North America and the Middle East.

(21) Countervailing measures have been applied under the Customs Tariff (Anti-dumping Act) 1975, where the conditions set down in the Act have been met. These conditions are consistent with the GATT and the GATT Subsidies Code. Tariffs applied to imported goods are established at tariff levels consistent with the Government's tariff and industry policy and are applied on a most favoured nation basis. Tariffs are not related specifically to the existence of a subsidy in one or more supplying countries. The appropriate mechanism to nullify a subsidy is a countervailing duty.
(22) The reasons for the non-application of measures inconsistent with the GATT are given in the answers to questions 17 to 19.

asked the Minister for Land Transport, upon notice, on 16 October 1991:

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Government's $200 million Urban Public Transport Program arose out of the Government's social justice concerns and is specifically targeted at the locationally disadvantaged in outer urban areas. The criteria used to assess the suitability of projects for funding are:
reduce wear and tear and/or congestion on urban arterial roads;

improving service and transport efficiency in outer metropolitan areas, with particular focus on areas with high concentrations of disadvantaged groups, in keeping with the Government's social justice objectives of generating improved access between the location of housing and the location of employment, education, training opportunities and social and recreational objectives;
providing environmentally and socially innovative solutions to urban public transport problems; and
demonstrating how the project fits in with States' public transport policies.
The Government considers that the Victorian Government's Light Diesel Rail Passenger Vehicle, "Sprinter", proposal satisfied these criteria.

Additionally, the Victorian Public Transport Corporation undertook a project appraisal into options for the provision of additional capacity on V/Line's commuter passenger services. The study, undertaken in October 1989 and updated in mid-1990, concluded that the "Sprinter" option ``will provide operational cost benefits over the least cost option ... in the order of $4.6 million per annum [December 1988 dollars]. The additional investment above the Base Case provides a Net Present Value of $15 million (at 4% discount rate), an Internal Rate of Return of 8% and a payback in 10 years after the first major capital investment.'' In other words, of the options identified in the study, the "Sprinter" option was shown to be financially the most economical.

The study found further that ``in addition to financial benefits, "Sprinters" provide travel time savings to commuters by virtue of their faster acceleration and travel speed. These travel time savings have been estimated at approximately $1.1 million per annum. In addition, road pavement costs avoided by not providing coach services will be saved and they are in the order of $120,000 to $140,000 per annum. The inclusion of these benefits in the analysis provides a Net Present Value of $33.6 million (at 4% discount rate) and an Internal Rate of Return of 13.4%.''
The Victorian Public Transport Corporation report did not disaggregate the project appraisal into individual routes.

(2) Yes. (3) Yes.
(4) The Victorian Public Transport Corporation has provided the following information:

(5) Yes. TALK.START.PARA: —On 3 September 1991 (Hansard page 558) the honourable member for Groom asked the following question, without notice, during the adjournment debate:

PARA.TAB: Will the remaining Voyager compensation cases be allowed by the Commonwealth to run their natural course through the Courts of this land?
The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
Yes. He should not however imply from this answer that the Commonwealth will not take proper steps to ensure that the cases are conducted as the law requires.

The honourable member prefaced his question addressed during the adjournment debate by referring to a case of Clarke v. The Commonwealth. That case first came on before Mr Justice Coldrey and, at the conclusion of the opening address for the plaintiff, counsel for the Commonwealth made an application for discharge of the jury on the ground that the address had been inflammatory, misleading and inaccurate. His Honour found that there was a real risk of irrelevant and prejudicial statements included in the opening address improperly influencing the jury and granted the application. I do not consider that the course adopted in that case was in any way improper or that it involved a legal technicality and accordingly, the same course may well be adopted if the same circumstances were to re-occur.
